description:
How did I get so lucky to have Réveille Coffee Co. as my neighborhood coffee shop? Réveille is the perfect mix of hipster, modern and chic and located in the heart of the Castro. They offer full breakfast and a wide variety of sweet and savory items, ranging from avocado toast (because duh!) to scones and almond croissants. Their coffee is top-notch and the baristas know damn well how to make a latte look like a piece of art.

Did someone say, "On Wednesday's we wear pink?" because at Réveille, two charming baristas - Oscar and Dan - coordinate their outfits (which are always on fleek) and fill the space with energy and create a sense of community I'm happy to be a part of. If you have the time, be sure to give them a visit and leave a tip for their excellent customer service.
author: Bryan D.

description:
Host/ess: n/a
Cashier: 1.0
Food-taste/presentation: 3.2
Property-ambiance/decor: 3.0

A very fresh and refreshing breakfast destination.
author: Rrr V.

description:
Little bummed right now from the misleading yelp page listing free wifi. I came here specifically for wifi and ordered my food and drink. After unable to find a network name and asking the barista, I found out the WiFi is only available on weekdays.

Update: They gave me a partial refund but I guess there still needs a way for it to be not misleading to other customers.
author: Gabriel C.

description:
A spot that seemed to be dominated by people working, Reveille didn't have the same warmth that other cafes in SF have, but they still serve up a nice latte. Literally every table inside was occupied by one person on a computer or a phone, all in a line facing the counter. It felt like a satire.

That being said, the area in the front seems better for gathering with a friend and feels a bit organic. 

My latte was solid, though there seemed to be something missing from my friend's dirty chai, maybe a little less chai than expected, as it was missing some of the earthy and spiciness we usually associate with dirty chais. Can't win them all, but still a fine choice.
author: Jess L.

description:
It's a modern style coffee bar in the heart of the Castro district. I came here for breakfast one weekend morning and had the "Shakshuka," a bold breakfast item that consisted of a poached egg that was swimming in chickpeas, some spicy tomato sauce, which I think had some jalapenos even, although my memory is a bit fuzzy. I also had one of their very smooth and strong cups of coffee.

Let me just say that the Shakshuka and coffee did not go together like two peas in a pod. Next time, I'd probably opt for the more traditional breakfast sandwich (which looks delicious from the pictures), but I did enjoy all the flavors of the Shakshuka; it was great to try it once, but it just felt weird eating something like that for breakfast with a hot cup of coffee. Guess I'm just not used to it.

A+ gold star for myself for a healthy choice though! I enjoyed the atmosphere here, especially in the morning with the electronic music playing; felt like I was in a fancy hotel lobby or something..ha.
author: Alex L.

description: The epitome of the perfect coffee shop! Gorgeous interior design, friendly hipster staff, super high quality coffees. Great place to work with WiFi during the week- no WiFi on weekends! Only downside is their pastry selection is quite stale and boring, however the food menu is awesome. Order a PB&J...
author: Sandra L.

description: I love this place and they know it! It's mostly because of the outdoor seating, or the coffee, or the avocado toast ?!? Well I love it all... besides... 90% when we order to the table, there is some item that never gets to our table and then we need to go back and ask for it and realize that our avocado toast never went for order?! Not sure if it's the machine behind the orders or what but that part has happened so so many times while rushing to work that it's not even funny anymore! Oh well let's see how it will go next days, I will keep returning! Also, really do get the avocado toast or salmon one, is the bomb!!
author: Irina P.

description: It is supposed this place opens at 7 am. Third time in a month I went to grab coffee at 7. 20 am and they are not open. They said are having some troubles with coffee machine. If this happens so often they shouldn't advertise they are open at 7 am everyday.
author: Monica B.

description:
Reveille is an adorable coffee shop. There's a gorgeous outdoor seating area that's literally covered in leaves and whatnot from trees (it's even prettier when the flowers are blooming!). Great spot for people watching or doing some work. There's ample seating indoors too. It's a hip establishment serving up delicious coffee, and the staff are super friendly as well! 

I've tried a few items from Reveille. The coffee is pretty great! Not the best I've ever had, but it's a solid cup of joe. I've also had soy cappuccinos from here and they're delicious as well -- strong but not overwhelming. I had the avocado toast here the other day with a fried egg. It was lackluster PRIMARILY because of the toast. It was far too stiff and crunchy, which, with how it was served, made it very difficult to eat (had to cut it with fork and nice because of the fried egg). Mind you, the presentation was beautiful. It came out on a black chunk of wood. So hip. Ya know how we do in SF. If the toast was served on a different type of bread or better bread ya know, it would be perfect. Good amount of avocado and the fried egg was perfectly cooked. That's my only qualm. Wouldn't order the avocado toast here again but DEFINITELY would come here for coffee. Often.
author: Amy T.

description: Beautiful place, very cozy, delicious coffee. Keep in mind that they stop serving food after 4pm.
author: Art K.

description:
The coffee was phenomenal.  Though, I ordered to-go and they had me in a cup to stay.  So, I stayed.  I enjoyed.  It was nice, busy.... but nice.

The food looked amazing, but maybe well try that next time around.  The neighborhood is lovely, so you can also grab a to go latte and enjoy a walk around.  Again, coffee was delicious.
author: Susanna O.

description:
Always looking for a great coffee shop to walk into. They have a beautiful entrance and outside sitting area and the baristas are very helpful. The coffee is very well made and the to go cups are creatively made! 

Probably one of my favorite places to go for flat whites. The inside sitting area is a little tight, but you can stay and study if you don't mind the limited space. There is WiFi but only on weekdays. I'll definitely recommend this coffee shop if you don't want your Phil'z down the street or Starbucks next door. 

I will definitely be back to try the food; which looks amazing.
author: Daw M.

description:
Delicious . Great price and high quality. I love this place. Lovely staff. 
Recommended!!!!
author: Hani G.

description:
I keep coming back & I keep mostly getting an overly hot, unbalanced espresso drink for my troubles. Every month, or so, I try again. I'm either an optimist or a dope. Probably the latter. 

Other than inconsistent espresso drinks, this cafe is fine, but the outside seating is what does it for me. Without that bit of light and air, one would be relegated to a boxy, dark space (that I think actually is a garage-conversion) that would make a claustrophobic feel anxious. The often groovy, but just a tad too loud music doesn't help. It's a small space where patrons often come to chat while they eat/drink & one should set the music level accordingly. The test is if you can't hear what the chick at the register not two feet from you is asking, then the tunes are too loud. 

*good location
*fairly clean loo
*hit or miss on the espresso drinks
author: Bea B.

description: Very bitter coffee, not that friendly staff, and bad wifi. The opposite of what you want in a  coffee shop. Good vibe in general but lacking on the basics. They can do way better.
author: Noel S.

description: Great coffee and a good menu for food and snacks for being a coffee shop. I had a salmon and cream cheese toast with capers on it and it was delicious! I could have devoured two more. This was prepared already, or you can order other food items from their menu. Coffee selection was great as well and a very cute cafe with an outside patio!
author: Xi-Er D.

description:
Réveille Coffee is my favorite in the whole city!!!

I usually go to their coffee truck in FiDi, but I ended up at the Castro location.

I ordered the Quinoa Salad and the Avo Toast, which were both excellent. I was also pleasantly surprised by how big the salad was.

Service was excellent and the location itself is beautiful. I love the outdoor seating in the front. Perfect for the warmer weather. The only bummer was that they don't have WiFi on the weekends, so I couldn't really get that much work done.
author: Teresa C.

description:
Really enjoyed the interior of this place but hot damn does this small space get busy. The coffee was pretty darn good and I thoroughly enjoyed the kind of decor on both the inside and outside. It all felt very comfortable to me!

The service was great, everyone was super friendly. However, when this place gets crowded you really do have to box your way out of this small space. Nonetheless, still an excellent option to grab some food and a drink!
author: Michael C.

description: Cute coffee place in Castro. Stopped by for a latte and cappuccino the other day. Nice vibe, great coffee and bright place to get some work done.
author: Sudipto G.

description:
Cute interior and exterior, lots of seating inside and outside makes this place optimal for getting work done. BUT there's no free wifi on the weekends -- probably because it gets crowded and they want to keep the flow of customers rolling. 

I had a cappuccino and avocado toast, both were good but the cappuccino wasn't as warm as I would've liked (nbd). Some of the customers and staff are kind of snooty here, I didn't get good vibes which is something I look for at local coffee shops. :(
author: Hana S.

description:
Hey Reveille,

So I was looking for something for breakfast.
Something to jump start my day of work.
Something quick, something simple but also something good and somewhat hearty.

Then I saw you. So I went. The Reveille Breakfast Sandwich looked pretty good so I ordered.

It was pricey, more than i was hoping to pay for my morning meal, but hey it was my first time with you so just this once and...

The breakfast sandwich was pretty darn good and it looked fancy with the egg baked into the bread and all. 

Unfortunately I can only speak to your sandwich because that's all I ordered this time. Yea I didn't order coffee. I know I am an evil human being. Next time I promise! Decor was nice, simple, quaint. I'll visit again soon.
author: Paul L.

description: Perfect place to study, bullet journal, read or fit in me time! The place is very cute and the perfect amount of loud. They have a very simple menu which I can appreciate. The avocado toast was amazing. Crunchy and a good amount of avocado! Not that mushed up BS where you don't know how much avocado is going on. It's simple with olive oil, salt and pepper. The coffee was good and perfect temperature. I hope to try the other breakfast items because they look amazing and smelled even better.
author: Caitlyn S.

description:
This is one of the Reveille locations, which is located in Castro. I've been to the other location in the Dogpatch area and really liked the vanilla latte and the ambience at that location. Here at the Castro location, it is a lot smaller and dimmer. The venue itself is more crowded. There is seating outside which looked pretty cute but inside there's bar seating in the center and table seating lining one of the walls. 

I ordered an iced latte and it came in a very cute glass cup. The coffee itself wasn't very strong and the flavor got diluted by the ice very quickly. You can ask for the wifi password, and the internet here is very fast and reliable. There are no outlets here however so you should come here with your laptop fully charged if you plan on getting work done for a few hours. The music here wasn't my favorite so it got a bit distracting after a while and overpowering compared to other cafes. Overall, this wasn't my favorite studying environment although wifi was good. I do prefer the other Reveille location to this one.
author: Catherine S.

description:
This is the extremely very close to castro street edition of reveille coffee.

Parking? You wish. There is the usual and semi mythical street parking, but like lot a lot of other things in the city you are best served by getting here some other way that does not involve driving. 

There are a lot of two spot type table chair combos along with a long center counter/bar and a limited amount of super awesome outside patio style seating. Unusually for the area the outside seating is wooden counter and bar stools or ledges. That along with some excellent landscaping make the patio seating a very nice option. The inside non counter spots tend to fill up with laptop campers, but even so there is generally room for one or two more.

The decor is brand new and very welcoming. Lots of earth tones, warm colors and low lights, not to mention the rotating local art adorning the walls. The overall effect is very welcoming. While the coffee trends towards slightly better then starbucks quality that's not all that big a deal in a city with some truly epic coffee places especially given the starbucks level pricing. The menu items tend to be better then you might expect. The avocado toast is pretty much always a win, and is highly recommended as a noshable  selection. Service is the by now standard of order at counter and wait for order to be called out model. There may be a line but it moves quick and if it's busy they'll just bring the food out to you.

So with wonderful ambiance, a great menu and good verging on great coffee this is overall a great coffee hangout.
author: Steven W.

description: Very good and strong coffee. I drink it black and it wasn't bitter. I also enjoyed the tasty avocado toast. Croissants and pastries also are consistently good.
author: Karen J.

description: The coffee is so yummy!  The cappuccino art is on point!  The wait is not usually long, but there is often a wait as the coffee is very good.
author: Danielle S.

description: I am a huge fan of Mark Rothko's art, so naturally I was drawn to the branding of this coffee roaster. While visiting, I gave their cappuccino a try and I absolutely fell in love. It was wonderful to say the least. The cafe has wonderful interior design, but this time I had to opt for the outside seating - which was absolutely magnificent and in a great neighborhood of San Francisco!
author: Andrew U.

description: They don't have WiFi on the weekends nor allow you to get on your hotspot - a little passive aggressive. Good avocado toast, though.
author: Bonnie C.

description: Close to my house, but this is first time come here lol. The most impressive​ thing about​ this store is the pink table. but I actually​  like inside of this store,  from the design style and the food and the drink.
author: Faye L.

description:
Reveille is a modern, hipster, and spacious cafe that makes one of my favorite cappuccinos ($4) in SF.

Tip: Free WIFI is only available on weekdays. For weekend visits, there's a speedy Xfinity hotspot for Xfinity/Comcast subscribers.
author: Hao H.

description:
I joined a friend here the morning of Memorial Day and the place was "line out the door" packed. First sign this place was going to be good. The second good sign, the cute decor. The ambiance is very inviting without being hipster pretentious. Plus the staff is super friendly and helpful. 

Luckily even though it was crowded we found a small table in the corner. My only complaint here would be that seating is a bit cramped so this definitely wouldn't be a place I would want to come to work out of if busy. 

I ordered an Americano and Avocado toast. Even with as busy as it was both came out quickly  and were delicious! I think I may have found my new favorite coffee spot in the area.
author: Tarah P.

description:
Réveille is a spacious and cute café great for lunch, brekkie, or a quick cup of coffee/tea. At any time, you can find friends chatting over some coffee, individuals reading or typing away on their laptops.
The quality of their coffees and teas are excellent. Their salads and sandwiches are also great. The smokehouse chicken sandwich is delicious. The almond milk chai latte is rich and aromatic. I highly recommend if you are in the area.
author: Jem S.

description:
I love so many things about this place. It's chill and all the food is really fresh and delicious, and it's a nice place to work with free decent wifi.  What a vast improvement over the nearby Starbucks. 

I'm dinging them a star because -- maybe this is petty - their farro quinoa salad has no farro in it. I've ordered that salad five times. It's a nice salad. But it's clearly "farro and quinoa" and there's never farro in it. Yesterday I even asked the cashier for the farro salad, and he said "you mean the farro and quinoa salad?" I said, "Yes, please - there's farro in it though, right?" and he confirmed. Alas, there was no farro in the salad. 

I really fucking like farro.
author: Becka R.

description:
It had been a while since I was in the Castro, and I was on the lookout for a cafe.  Réveille is located on 18th St near Castro Street, and it's a moderately sized cafe.  During the times that I visited, I've noticed many people working on their laptops, and I've found it a good place to read; though it often seems popular, it's never seemed noisy to me.  The wood panelling and soft lightening makes it an attractive place to sit for a while.  

My go-to coffee drink recently has been the Americano, and I've liked the Americanos that I get here.  Sometimes, baristas can pull espresso shots that are too bitter/acidic, but so far, that has not been the case at Réveille.  They do offer a food menu, and while I haven't tried any of their items, the salad at the table next to me looked pretty good.
author: Keith H.

description:
$4.60 and some change for the worst 10oz iced coffee. It's just ultra bitter and the service even more so! 

Wake up Castro, this is not worth slurping down. Do yourself a favor and pass on this place. You're better off heading to nearby Philz or making your way to Four Barrels.
author: Brandon J.

description: Very nice and modern cafe and a go to when needing an afternoon latte or one of their delicious salmon toasts.   Good music and friendly staff.   90% of the guests are deep into work on their laptops on weekdays, which is not my fave.
author: Scott H.

description:
One of my go-tos for a quick healthy lunch. The salads are great - I prefer the kale salad. The avocado toast is super simple - literally avocado on toast drizzled with EVOO - but sometimes simple is best. The flatbreads are large, but taste mediocre. Solid matcha latte.

There are a few tables along the wall that can fill up quickly, and a communal table in the middle. Additional seating outside underneath a canopy of green. Beware this place can get toasty when it's warm out. The service was not the friendliest. WiFi works well during the weekday. There is a lack of outlets besides the one by the counter.
author: Eva W.

description:
I'm shocked I haven't' reviewed this place because I've gone a ton. They have my favorite ice tea in the city. There's this crazy mint elderflower concoction they got that's incredible. Sadly you'll probably down it in 5 minutes and it's probably too expensive to get two.

I like the avocado toast well enough but while the slices look prettier than a mash, mash stays on the bread better.
author: Misha T.

description:
Great coffee. I would have given this place a 4 stars. 

But I asked for a large pour over but they stick to a tiny cup of pour over coffee. I end up grabbing another coffee on my way home. Not cool!

Customer is always right - build or provide a few sizes of pour over coffee like other pour over places. Will not come back again.
author: Clint D.

description:
A nice, modern venue that draws a younger, professional crowd than, say, the Starbucks nearby, there's a reasonable amount of room to park yourself for a short time, whether at small tables or a communal bench inside, or in their glorious front patio that enables lots of people-watching.

Whether it's espresso drinks or pour overs, the coffee is decent, and they also serve breakfast items in the mornings, plus salads, sandwiches, and flatbreads in the afternoons. If it's not crowded inside, it would indeed be a preferred place for me to visit whenever I'm in the neighborhood, except for the fact that some of the servers can be indifferent at best or full of attitude at the worst.
author: Vincent L.

description:
Start the new year with trying a new coffee place. Unfortunately, Reveille(& many recent coffee shops that seem to be popular with hipsters and techies)fail to serve HOT coffee or cappuccinos/lattes. 

But, they can make a doodle design on your expresso drink. They also make sure they have an iPad payment system trying to push u into a high percent tip before even receiving your foods/beverages when paying with credit card.

No, I'm not an old geezer who needs his coffee and soups boiling hot. I'm just a guy who likes coffee(all forms) served the way it's supposed to be.

So if you like a tasty luke warm coffee or espresso drink this is your place.
author: L D.

description: I love their breakfast and tea.  My favorite is the avocado on toast or their peanut butter and nutela with bananas on top.   I also like their salads and egg sandwiches.
author: Parastoo E.

description: Great food, wonderful coffee, friendly and supportive staff. Cute, chic, classy cafe and coffee spot! Convenient location and warm atmosphere. Highly recommend.
author: Zoe M.

description:
Such a cute coffee spot in the castro!! I've passed a dozen times but never knew the name because of the beautiful jasmine that lines the awning of the cafe. 

I finally stopped in today with my friend and we ordered a cold brew and cappuccino. The cold brew was really good and came out in a cute mason jar! My friend really enjoyed his cappuccino as well and said it was strong but not too acidic. 

We sat out in the front which was great to people watch, and they brought out our food. I got (of course) avocado toast which tasted as good as it looked, and he got the flatbread which was surprisingly big for $10-- would def order this if you are on the hungrier side. Great place to bring a book and sit outside with your dog as well, which we saw many people doing-- I'll be back to do so myself!
author: Allie H.

description:
Oh such a pretty site. 

It's hidden under a Victorian house on Castro St and it couldn't be any more perfect. 

It seems like an enchanted forest when you first enter - with all the vines, greens, and wood that it's surrounded by. The lights make it super festive and all you want to do is sit on the wooden bar stools outside and people watch all day. 

The rustic feel makes it super cozy even on a chilly afternoon. 

And the coffee...well it's impeccable. Ordered a hot latte. Just the right amount of caffeine to keep you going, but not too much to make you feel as though you're on crack. 

Make sure to take your time and embrace what's around you.
author: Mary B.

description:
This coffee shop is truly a gem, an awesome addition to the Castro District. I stopped in for a morning latte, it's always a wonderful way to kick start my day. Friendly team members behind the counter plus prompt service. I truly admire them for taking time to carefully decorating latte art on to each coffee. As a result, the art on my latte is beautifully decorated. Coffee that is carefully crafted and artistically decorated is worth enjoying. A true symbol or a promise from the barista creating the drink. It means they truly care about customer satisfaction.

Pros:
Spacious coffee shop withe more seating available. More seating means better capability to accommodate patrons sitting to enjoy their coffee and pastry. Overall, positive first experience here so I'll definitely be back.

Cons: NONE

Reasons for rating:
- clean facility
- prompt service
- friendly team members
- spacious facility
- seating available inside / outside
author: Bennett W.

description:
Nice space. Bigger than I thought it would be and clean. Also if it were nice outside, the outdoor tables looked good as well (a little noisy because they are on  18th, but still pleasant).

Got an decaf americano.  It tasted like a decaf americano. Friends got tea. It tasted like tea - but did come in fancy glass pots. 

Avocado toast tasted like avocado toast - nice and ripe avo. 

I saw a bunch of food come out that looked really good. I'd like to go back form breakfast/brunch/lunch.

Wasn't too crowded on Saturday at noon, but maybe that's because it was raining.
author: Sarah C.

description: Adorable space with a delicious and well priced avocado toast for SF. Great to work but no outlets for your laptop. Unfortunately the coffee wasn't great- lacks complexity and it tasted like the beans the coffee were brewed from were stale and/or didn't spend enough time actually brewing with beans. Bitter and watered down coffee- I'm still sleepy!
author: Katrina C.

description:
Intimate, quiet, cozy, and great vibes. We ordered the Biscuit with house made jam, Avocado toast, and Egg sandwich. First let me applaud them on the portions of avocado. I actually, truly, enjoyed eating avocado with my meal and not having just a taste like every other place teases you with. 
Our two Cappuccino's were also incredible. The taste was just enough to wake me up and not too strong where I couldn't finish it. The design also had me taking pictures. 
Keep doing what you're doing, you've got a happy customer in me.
author: Nicole A.

description:
Oh, pretty little cappuccino, you make my heart sing! 

I just love, love, love it when there is a caring, fancy, possible coffee snob, throwin' down some precious gifts of coffee and steamed milk for coffee feen/lovers/fanatics like me! 

You can get your fancy cappuccino, latte or whatever kind of coffee you happen to be craving here, along with a variety of breakfast items. I opted for that nice nectarine danish... but another time, I might go for one of those exciting egg sandwiches or something sensational from their mesmerizing menu! 

Can't wait to return... YUM.
author: Cassandra E.

description:
Reveille is a cute little coffee spot on 18th St, a stone's throw from the hustle and bustle of Castro St.  Tucked away under a Victorian, it's easy to walk right by and not notice it's there.

Atmosphere-wise, it's absolutely lovely.  Friendly staff, cozy seating, and a small patio ideal for people-watching.  Even on a busy weekend morning, I managed to snag a place to sit without much difficulty.

Unfortunately, the enjoyment ended once my coffee arrived.  I ordered a mocha, which was was bland and gritty.  This surprised me, since mochas are awfully hard to mess up.  (Coffee and chocolate?  How could that go wrong?)

I also had a bowl of yogurt and granola, which was fine but unremarkable.  The portion size was shockingly small for $7.  It was gone in just a few bites.  That was stingy even by San Francisco standards.

All in all, I'd say that San Francisco has better coffee shop options than Reveille.  I guess my standards are higher in a city with one of the most competitive coffee shop scenes around.
author: David G.

description: Out of all the reveille coffees this is my favorite.  Great look, always perfect drinks and good food.  One of the best almond iced lattes.  Great service.  Eclectic customers, hipster.
author: Diane V.

description: I was debating on going to Starbucks or Philz while I was in the Castro, which are close by from this cafe, but I'm glad I skipped out and tried something new. Enjoyed a delicious almond milk latte and avocado toast. Steep prices, but not unexpected when in San Francisco. The aesthetics of Reveille was simplistic and clean. The service was very fast and friendly, especially during a weekend morning/brunch rush. Will definitely come back when in the area and visiting Roha: Center for the Healing Arts (few doors down the street - also highly recommend).
author: Sofia B.

description: Smallish inside but really cool little spot. The avocado toast was pretty crunchy but tasted great. Latte was great. Everyone was nice and they had some outdoor seating.
author: Nifer S.

description:
Come here every weekend to see my friends and have a cup of latte. It's my favorite spot with one of the best lattes, I've ever had! 
Love their tuna salad - portion is huge, very delicious!!!
Place is cozy, always crowded - Especially crazy on Saturday and Sunday. 
Baristas and cashiers are nice, always smiling and sending positive vibes. Beka and Alina - my favorite girls over there.
author: Mariia N.

description:
This cafe has a really nice atmosphere for working or just chilling with your friends. Service was quick and friendly. It's pretty small with an average of two people per table. 
Breakfast is served only before 11:30am. I came around 10:30am and there wasn't a line, but it was packed. Luckily I found one table open. They also have a beautiful sitting area on the outside.  
I got the avocado toast and a latte with almond milk. They weren't special, but I would definitely come back to try out more of their menu.
author: Grace Z.

description: Wonderful coffee paired with a delicious biscuit and jam! My go to when in the Castro. Staff is always friendly and lines go fast. Great place!
author: Danielle H.

description:
If you come here you do so for the ambiance. A cup of mint tea can only be so good.

I like the place though. Fast friendly service in a clean bathroom. 

Only reason for a 3, and not a 4-star review is the cigarette smokers like to perch outside so the whole restaurant is overcome with cigarette smoke smell.
author: scott h.

description: Small, local, with friendly service and a beautiful outdoor space. Simply perfect! And the Tuna salad sandwich is to die for! Yum!
author: Randy D.

description:
This is a solid place to go get some coffee and a quick brunch. I got myself a Cappuccino (pictured) and a Shakshuka which was really great although not ordering the Avocado toast required more restraint on my part than I thought. 

My only real gripe is that they can fill up quite a bit over the weekend which results in not much place to sit around if and relax if you're the type to read a book or get some work done.
author: Gouthaman K.

description:
I have always enjoyed grabbing a latté or just a good cup of joe when in the 'Stro. The décor is nice and they recently covered up the front area in vines for some shade.

Although I am usually fond of this cute coffee shop, they do not handle the rush well. It's pretty much chaos. The staff come off as rude and cannot be bothered attitude.
author: Myron J.

description: One of my favorite spots to get work done. They don't have any plugs to speak of so come with a full charge but they do provide wifi. The vibe is chill and friendly and they have a nice selection of food items so that you can eat and not need to leave in the middle of a work session without filling up on pastries. I understand the points the lower reviewers are making but those things just aren't why I love this place. There are so many different reasons to enjoy a coffee shop and these are mine! Enjoy!
author: Justin S.

description: Cozy little cafe in Castro. Very nice atmosphere, good latte and sandwich. Friendly staffs and all nice people skittle around me. Good chillax place. I like the outdoor sitting which I can bring my bird with me and seeing the neighbors. Good spot for coffee or brunch.
author: Katie M.

description: I came today out of spontaneity and to study with a friend. I ordered an iced vanilla latte and it was refreshing. I loved the way they made it and how quick. My friend got a soy vanilla latte and she also enjoyed her drink. I came on a Sunday (& Mother's Day) so it was pretty slow but I enjoyed it. I was able to do my work. They do not have wifi on weekends though! I definitely would come back again.
author: Angelyn M K.

description:
Came here to meet up with some friends for coffee on a Friday morning. At first I didn't recognize it because the sign is set back behind the ivy surrounding the patio area. It's a super cute coffee shop that gets fairly crowded. There was a bit of a line when we went to go order, but it went quickly. If you order food, they give you a number and they bring it to you. If you order coffee, you just pick it up at the counter.

I ordered a latte and it was pretty good (and cute latte art!).

My friends ordered the avocado toast and grapefruit brûlée (which comes as two halves). Both looked delicious!

Typical SF prices and good coffee!
author: Leana L.

description: I ate the chicken sandwich (but with green goddess aioli instead of whatever spread it came with) and it was sooooo good. The bread had crusty texture and superb chew, the chicken was fresh and really juicy, even the side salad was tasty. This is just the kind of modern, albeit pricey, experience I want from the hip Castro.
author: Laura G.

description: This is an amazing gem in the Castro.  Great coffee, yummy food, super friendly staff and a fun vibe. You'll find good music, people working, reading books and catching up over great food and drinks.  This is a good place to go to get energized, be inspired and eat healthy delicious food.
author: Jeffrey E.

description:
Quintessential San Francisco coffee shop -- minimalist interior with $5 mochas. Pros: cool vibes, quality food/coffee; Cons: small space, weird coffee flavor 

Food: My friend and I came in here for a coffee break in the Castro -- ordered a latte (~$5) and a macchiato (~$3). Lattes are absolutely enormous, served in an almost-bowl mug. You can tell they have baristas that know what they're doing, but whatever beans they were using that morning had a really strange flavor. It was strongly citrusy which tasted somehow off with the steamed milk. However, I'd probably give them the benefit of the doubt and commend them on having coffee that actually has a flavor of some sort. Would try again. 

Atmosphere: Beautifully designed, all wood interior. Classic SF vibes. It's quite small though, so not a place I'd feel working at for extended periods of time. 

Value: On the high end for coffee... classic SF prices. 

Service: Cashier was kind! No complaints.
author: Deena M.

description: Reveille has been a staple in the Castro and while their décor and atmosphere is very welcoming, the staff cannot handle rushes very well. I was also very surprised that a coffee place could run out of cold brew...During warm summer days in SF, one would think a coffee shop would be well equipped with gallons of cold brew at least. Luckily, the nice barista recommended an iced americano for me instead. Cute place, but their ventilation system sucks. It was very stuffy and hot inside the café when I visited.
author: Kenneth L.

description:
Ridiculously cute cafe in a ridiculously trendy neighborhood. 

Unfortunately, the parking situation is an absolute nightmare. So hard to get to. 

After circling around three times in neighboring blocks to find parking, at a crawl because of the auto and pedestrian traffic, mind you, I gave up trying to "sit and relax" in this cafe. But I was still determined to try their drinks. So I got dropped off across the street while the husband circled around some more (no choice really).

Mint Hibiscus Iced Tea - Just the right blend of mint and hibiscus. I added a bit of their agave sweetener to play the hibiscus up a bit and it is now my new favorite tea. 

Cafe Mocha - very good. Could totally taste the coffee AND the chocolate.

Lots of cute guys. 

Lots of peeps on their laptops too. WiFi must be free but I couldn't stay long enough to find out.
author: Kislev A.

description:
Pros: I really enjoyed the ambiance- when I went, it was very chill and not crowded at all.

Cons: The barista was very awkward and couldn't answer any of my questions. The iced tea selections were really subpar- just black and hibiscus. I asked to make sure the hibiscus has no added sweeteners, just tea. It came out tasting like cherry cough syrup or something. Gross! They also have no wifi on weekends, which was why I came here in the first place. I ended up tossing the $5 tea and going to Starbucks down the street instead. It's a pity because it's such a cute location!
author: Brenna S.

description: Walking into the fresh smell of roasted coffee is always a pleasure. My friend introduced me to this little gem during my visit in San Francisco, and I'm glad he did! I ordered a macchiato (about $3.25) and he ordered a green tea ($4-6). The macchiato is not what Starbucks goers are used to... Instead, it comes in a small cup with a cute design on top. It is an easy way to wake yourself up! The green tea comes hot in a little teapot. After adding honey to it, it gives your heart a little sweet warmth in the chilling temperatures of San Francisco.
author: Jennifer L.

description: This is a beautiful coffee shop. It's got a really nice interior and a small outdoor area. I love coming here to do work/procrastinate. Just wish there were more outlets!
author: Henry Z.

description:
Excellent coffee, great people-watching location lol, and apparently great toast, though I have not had the pleasure of trying the toast here.

I ordered an almond milk mocha and got some work done at the "bar" area.  The mocha was great...creamy, fantastic espresso beans, and you can tell they take time to make each beverage.  

I like how the place is very welcoming, too-from the baristas, to the open door, to the fact that people who come in here seem nice-Yes, they may keep to themselves, but they're all there to be at this it-spot (for the coffee, for the toast, to get work done, to hang, to check people out, and the list goes on).

I was shocked at how many people came in the 2.5 hours I was there.  I have only been here twice but I like the area it is in and I like the coffee.  Will be back fo' sho'!
author: Monica J.

description:
Awesome vibes with indoor and outdoor seating. Great for a few hours of work or grabbing coffee/tea with a friend or two. They even had looseleaf tea that comes in a teapot and mug - I had the puerh which was decent. 

Note: wifi is fast, but there are no outlets, so come fully charged if you're trying to work.
author: Inga C.

description:
On a Saturday, mid-day, I was in the Castro looking for a coffee place. I first stopped at Philz but the line was too long and there was no seating. The typical Tesora would have been nice but I left exploring for somewhere else. 

I decided to stray from Castro St, and walk down 18th. That's when I encountered this gem. I noticed people chillin' in the vine draped patio area, drinking cappuccinos or having a late afternoon hot meal. Although this place appears to be primarily a coffee shop, it has a few hot dining options as well. Which is a bit hit or miss because when I'm having coffee, I don't really want the whiff of mustard. 

Cool vibe inside--mellow acoustic guitar in the background, the patio greenery flowing inside, industrial looking grey concrete flooring, a long white bench with soft cushions, and most curiously wall-to-wall light brown wooden tiling which extended across the ceiling. In a way, it felt as though the ceiling and floor should be reversed. The trippy black and white tiling all across the counter added a nice contrast to the overwhelming wood theme. A bit on the loud side (with the typical inane chatter in the background), and the lighting is dim, so I'd say it's a place that's better for catching up with friends than working on anything requiring your focus. 

I ordered the latte and chocolate chip cookie. The latte was satisfying, smooth medium blend. The chocolate chip cookie was thick, with salt pieces on top; also satisfying. 

Overall, not a bad choice if you're looking to find a unique spot to meet up with a friend on a Saturday afternoon.
author: Behnam S.

description:
I only come here when my favorite barista is working, and now that Rebecca has left I have no reason to be back. Her face is always so sweet and welcoming, and she takes time with every drink. She even remembers tons of regulars names and orders! 
I've been here tons of times when others have made my drinks, and everything was mediocre and/or had to be adjusted to be drinkable. 
$9 for burnt granola and $4.25 for a latte are a little more painful when Rebecca's not there!
author: Emma G.

description:
This is San Francisco. You can get some of the best coffee in the nation here. Don't settle for Réveille. To me at least, the espresso is overpriced, lacking in flavor, and weak.

They've also branched into juices and juice shots. This means you can now pay $4 for a couple ounces of water mixed with turmeric.

And the food is even worse (to me, at least). I've tried one of their breakfast sandwiches (the one with merguez), and on another occasion, my friend tried a different breakfast sandwich. Both were doused in an overpowering sauce and were just not tasty.

Also, some the staff can be pretentious. Asking for any modification to anything can get you a sneer. I once asked if they do iced cappuccinos, and was given a lecture on how they don't do that because it requires throwing away steamed milk. Couldn't they just not throw it away, or increase the ratio of foam to steam? Another time, I asked if it's possible to reduce the sugar on my matcha latte order, and was just told "no, sorry" (no explanation, though I'm assuming they pre-mix their matcha with sugar, which is fine).

That all said, the one thing that is worth trying, if you're already here, is their matcha latte. I get it iced, and it's delicious.

For people who work around Mission Bay, there aren't a ton of options. For people who live anywhere else in SF, I suggest trying something else.
author: Sravanthi K.

description: Love the toast with avocado on top. They also have almond milk. Sweet decor too :)
author: Freya-Loki O.

description: This was my WORST coffee experience EVER. Worse was that it was my friends as well. We both are coffee enthusiasts and very disappointed by our drinks. The employees (both male) were not helpful at all. The register boy didn't know anything about the pour overs and the so called barista sucked at creating a simple latte. I ordered a $7 pour over and the register kid reacts with "you sure you want that one, you know it costs $7???" Man I know what I ordered don't need you to tell me how much money I want to spend on MY COFFEE. Oh and look at the bad quality latte I ended up picking off of the counter...
author: Citlali G.

description:
Compared to the cacophony of the Columbus Avenue location where United Nations delegations pass through at alarming rates, this Réveille has a downright low-key vibe, and this is the Castro for Harvey's sake. It may be because I was here a half-hour before closing when all the overly caffeinated hipsters were already in rehab shelters for the night. I liked the look of the place with the front patio made for serious gawking and the neo-vintage cross-hatch wallpaper and faux-firewood accent wall made for the interior decorator in all of us (photo: http://bit.ly/1IlDYeL). I've heard tell of the fabulous Avocado Toast ($4.50/$6.50 with fried egg) and Shakshuka, a pricey poached egg with roasted tomato and chickpea ($11).

But alas, I never think about having an actual meal at Réveille, but I'll fix that misconception at some point. In the meantime, I decided to saunter in after a hearty bowl of Spicy Oxtail Pho at Mekong Kitchen across the street. There were only two laptoppers in the place, so I had plenty of choice as to where to sit. The $4.50 Mocha calmed my fiery digestive system in no time at all (photo: http://bit.ly/1OMqyMB). The Newbury brothers, Tommy and Chris, started Réveille in a delivery truck five years ago, and while they're not yet in the same playpen as Philz or Blue Bottle, I like the richness and finishing style they display with their coffee. Besides, they're not nearly as pretentiously elitist as they are at Sightglass. Oh no, he didn't. Oh yeah, I went there.

COFFEE - 4 stars...silky goodness in that mocha
AMBIANCE - 3.5 stars...the trendiness comes off as trendy but somehow it works
SERVICE - 3.5 stars...nicer than anyone at Sightglass
TOTAL - 4 stars...give it up for the Traveling Newburys
author: Ed U.

description:
Avocado, egg, and coffee. Throw in a cute little shop with a cool ambience and friendly workers. What else do you need? When you walk into Reveille (reh-vay) coffee co, it gives you that feeling like you just found a good one. 

I don't know what it is about avocado toast that makes it so amazing. Yes I could just make it at home, but eating it at a cute shop is always better! There egg in a hole toast sandwich thing (actually just called egg sandwich) was super filling and delicious. It had bacon, braised kale and leek, and gruyere. The bread is toasted to perfection and the top piece of bread has an egg in it. So much simplicity going on, but so good.

Only downside would be parking and space to sit. It gets crowded so you may have to stalk people to get a table.
author: Maleah M.

description:
love this spot. 
GREAT coffee 
and good food. 
and an outdoor area!
and the staff is 99% great as well. 

they get 5 stars for that, but there is one french girl who is a total buzz kill. like she's too cool to smile or talk to anyone. she's such a downer that if i go in and she's working i actually LEAVE or wait for someone else to take a turn at the register.
author: Sara S.

description:
The avocado toast. 
It's so simple, but so good. 
It's so simple that it's actually kind of dumb how fantastic it is. 
It's so simple that I fooled myself into thinking I could recreate it at home. 
I was wrong. 
So very, very wrong. 
Everything I make looks like cat food. 


Ingredients: Avocado, Salt + Pepper, Olive Oil, Acme Levain
It's $4.50.
You can also add a fried egg (I do) for an additional $2


This place is within' a downhill walk from my best friend's place.
Perfect for those sudzy nights where I need to couch crash. 
Even better for those hungover mornings where calories and single-stall bathroom with a good flush are necessary.
They have great coffee here.
So great that even a person like me who appreciates creamer more than coffee can stomach it black. 
Though their iced tea is pretty on point and far better for the hangover curing process than a mimosa. 


They have a few tables inside and a really nice, sunny patio.
It's super casual.
Order at the counter, wait with your number, then get brought back to life with this delicious dish. 
One day I'll get something else here.
Looking at you Shakshuka.
But until then, avocado toast dreams all the way.
author: Candice G.

description:
I had a rough morning at work, and decided to treat myself to lunch at Reveille Coffee.  I ordered the Chinese chicken salad, which was $12.50.  It turned out to be a pretty big salad, probably good for two people if they weren't too hungry.  Even though I was starving, I found myself to be really full after eating 3/4 of it.

The rice wine vinegar dressing is what I liked most about this salad.  Having fresh ingredients helps too.

The vibe, at least on a workday afternoon, is pretty chill.  Everyone kept to themselves on their devices.  I needed the quiet though.

It was too late for me to drink coffee (I'm sensitive to caffeine) so I will have to come back earlier in the day and get a cup.
author: Vira P.

description: The matcha lattes were a delight. This underground joint isn't really the Castro vibe but is still hopping with the sleek urban outfitters wood vibe. Great service they really picked me up after having a bad experience at the nearby Philz coffee. Most of the people sit on the nice outside patio giving it a more pure ambiance.
author: Carmen B.

description:
Ordered a breakfast sandwich, they had a discussion in the kitchen and with the person who took my order, but never came to speak to me. So instead of bringing what I ordered, they brought it the way they thought it should be with no explanation. Even after I tried to correct the error they did declined. I returned the sandwhich and left, unhappy to have paid so much, and a $3 tip on top of it. 

The place remains popular, but I won't be back. Therre are plenty of other places that serve with a smile to those willing to shell out $20 for a quick breakfast in SF.
author: Scott N.

description: Very cute tucked away coffee house with food and excellent coffee. Nice friendly people work here! With outdoor seating this is the perfect place to relax and get a coffee or snack.
author: Victoria N.

description:
The coffee a cafe reveille will wake you up and turn you around. 

No matter your stripe, you'll feel right after this.
author: John D.

description:
Cute little millennial spot on 18th Street.  I don't think I saw anyone over 25 years old there....working or sipping.  Laptops everywhere and nobody in any hurry to leave....
Very SF with a hint of tattooed attitude.  The coffee itself was very good but not sure why they couldn't bring it to us considering we were sitting at the small counter as soon as you walk in.  Instead, I had to maneuver through a tight space when they called my order and pick it up myself.  Making my way around a tight corner filled with people in line waiting to order,--- when the coffee maker was less than 2 feet from us--- just pissed me off. This happened twice--once for the macchiato and again for the latte.  They served us the coffee cake and pound cake at the counter--not sure why coffee would be different.
It's these little things that annoy consumers. 
Blame it on clueless customer service.
It's amazing that yet another garage on this block has become a business.
http://www.millennialmarketing.com/who-are-millennials/
author: Thomas D.

description: They have excellent coffee, delicious hipster egg dishes on artisanal bread, and decent wifi. Prices aren't cheap, but what is in SF?  It's especially popular on weekends, but pretty easy to find a seat mid-week.
author: Rachel R.

description: See my photo of the $4.50 avo toast I bought here that had a big fucking hole in it. Take your business elsewhere - I certainly will from now on.
author: Emily D.

description:
This place has definitely got the hipster vibes going! Definitely a nice place to go if you like cafe background noise when you're studying. 

I got a mug of coffee (love places that offer this) and an amazing bacon biscuit. Yum. They do eggs and other stuff for breakfast as well. We also snuck in one of the deadly cookies - yum! One of the cashiers is Danish - not sure why that's relevant, but it made my Danish husband very happy.
author: Jennie C.

description:
I came here on a Saturday morning around 9 a.m. and it was already starting to get busy! Modern, minimalist interior and a beautiful patio to enjoy your coffee outside. They serve breakfast until 1 p.m. on weekdays, but all day on the weekends!

I ordered the avocado toast and a latte. The latte was good, but the avocado toast was amazing! They're very generous with the amount of avocado that they give you and the simple seasoning really brings out the flavor. The dish was beautifully prepared as well. Definitely looking forward to spending another morning here.

Unfortunately, they don't have wifi on the weekends, so if you're looking for a good weekend study spot, you'll have to look elsewhere!
author: Bonnie Z.

description: $4.80 for a cup of tea is bullshit, but it caught me off guard and so I did't walk out like I should have. The bitch at the counter took my $20, handed me $15 in bills and then dropped the two dimes change directly in her tip jar without even looking at me, and then told me to steep it for four minutes. Fuck this place.
author: Dale W.

description:
We met a human here! My girlfriends and I needed some caffeine after a long day walking the sinuosity of the SF streets. We checked Yelp and this was the closest coffee shop with character we could get in Castro area. Then...deception...one person per table not even consuming a drink and occupying the space with their tablets. Horrible situation and metaphor of the online connected/out of line disconnection with other people. 

And then we heard a voice. "Do you want to sit here, I gave you my table", murmured a soft spoken Chinese from NY just transplanted to SF. At this point, the rest of the coffee shoppers were like asleep in front of their devices, so un-romantic. Honestly, Reveille..reveille-toi! this should be a place to gather, drink, chit and chat, not an extension of your work stuff. Anyways, coffee was awesome and all nicely designed, plus guess what? We became friend of this gentle guy who invited me to go next week to see the awesome views from his Jackson Towers apartment (check my review and get jealous:).

Now that I think twice...this does not even seem a review for Reveille Coffee Co, but it is. I had a good time there, a nice drink, and the beginning of new great experiences. Keep it up and sack those who have roots in those chairs (without consuming).
author: Carmen V.

description: Really enjoyed the atmosphere - great location. Avocado toast was so flavorful and the orange juice was fresh squeezed. Great cappuccino as well. Next time will add the egg to the toast!
author: Tyler G.

description:
One of my new favorite coffee shops in San Francisco with delicious, reasonably priced food that rivals some of the better restaurants / lunch spots, a great ambiance, beautiful decor, and good coffee. What more can you ask for? (Other than WiFi on the weekends, but I can forgive that because it has everything else that I want)

My favorite thing on the menu is their salad which is full of seasonal vegetables (usually roasted potatoes, brussel sprouts, etc) and parmesan cheese. For $11-12, it's filling and satisfying enough for a meal. I could eat this every week and probably not get tired of it.

I've heard their avocado toast is also delicious and I'll have to try it next time I'm here. But definitely a great place to come for lunch, a coffee, and do some work or reading. One of my favorite coffee shops in SF!
author: Christina L.

description:
Great coffee - love the pour overs!!
Would love to try their iced coffee on the next warm SF day.

Amazing avocado toast. Definately need to go here more when I am in the area.
author: Cicely T.

description:
Reveille Coffee Co. carries the best vanilla latte I have ever tasted! My love and infatuation for vanilla lattes have taken me from coffee shop to coffee shop around the Bay Area, but I think I've found a winner! My vanilla latte contained just the right amount of sweetness. In the opinion of a sweet tooth, I would say that this vanilla latte was more on the sweeter side, as some vanilla lattes I have tried can taste quite bitter.

Also, I really loved the outdoor decor of this coffee shop, as it felt very welcoming with the surrounding vines, modern wooden tables with stools, and beautiful hanging lights. The inside was very modern and organized as well. You can definitely come here with your laptop and get some work done, as I've seen more than 50% of the crowd here accompanied by their Macbooks - don't ask me about the Wifi though, I haven't tried it haha.

If you're ever in the Castro area, you HAVE to come here!
author: Michelle S.

description: Great coffee and good food but the prices are sort of offensive. Great ambience. Just wish they'd be a bit more reasonable in pricing.
author: Urban S.

description: I went today for lunch at their new location on Waller and Steiner.  It was really a great spot for a wonderful salad - and I saw a lot of great looking sandwiches at other tables.  I am a fan - I will be back. Nice neighborhood spot.
author: Marina O.

description: My new fav place for lattes, great staff, sandwiches, and of course avocado toast if you're in the Castro, skip Starbucks and come here. They've also got giant yummy salad bowls. Didn't try them, next time for sure!
author: Christine N.

description:
In search of good coffee....excellent cortado.  Great artistry and strong tasting.  This Reveille is nestled between Starbucks and Peets on 18th. Street in the Castro neighborhood.  Definitely worth walking around to find decent, good coffee!  

Seems like every barista works on perfecting the crescent!
author: Jewel C.

description:
It's so hard to keep up with these new coffee shops that specialize in espresso handcrafted drinks popping up in San Francisco, but I managed to finally come here after noticing the cute atmosphere the exterior provides with the string of lights over the outdoor seating. 

The interior reminds me of say, if Urban Outfitters had a coffee shop. It looks like it takes place in a garage under a house and has a very clean and cool feel to it. My friend I was with got their regular cup of house coffee while I opted for the mocha. I don't think their mocha is for everyone because it's not really sweet but more rich in chocolate, but it was just fine for me. It seems that this is another popular spot for coffee, as barely any seating was available. They also serve cafe food here such as sandwiches and salads which is a plus. I wish this kind of coffee wasn't expensive, but if I had the right budget I would probably come here often.

Next time, I'm going to try the dirty chai!
author: Kathleen S.

description:
I wish my garage was this chic. Surprisingly bright and cozy, black and white Moroccan tiling, tables and stools perfect for some company or going solo. There's also some outdoor space in the front - perfect for people watching. 

I ordered the avocado toast (without the fried egg this time, but count me in on my next visit!) and a capp. The coffee was good, and the food was even better. I saw a dad cut a pastry in half for his daughters, and I have to say that I'm also looking forward to ordering some sugar behind the glass case.
author: Natasha P.

description: Love this place. Super casual. Short menu but great food, smooth coffee and strong tea.
author: Nicolai S.

description: Might be the almond milk latte I've ever had and I'm from Seattle. It's pretty damn good.
author: Elle B.

description: A nice, modern venue that draws a younger, professional crowd. Such a cute coffee spot in the castro!
author: Mega Team R.

description:
A great coffee shop in the Castro! I came here with my friend on a Saturday morning and we got two cold brews, an avocado toast with a fried egg, and yogurt with granola. The cold brews were great - not too acidic. The avocado toast had good bread and the egg was also cooked nicely. I don't even like eggs normally, but my friend insisted on protein and toast to nurse my hangover. My friend's yogurt was super filling - big bowl with lots of granola and fruit. Also sheep's milk yogurt is used and is very good.

Great ambiance - super chill baristas, crowd of people, and fun music. People were here doing work, catching up with friends, or just grabbing coffee on the go. 

Will be back for sure!
author: Steph V.

description:
Reveille is one of the most efficiently packed coffee shops I have visited... talk about maximum seating capacity. With free WiFi, delicious food, and fresh coffee, how can you NOT be tempted to spend an entire morning or afternoon here?

For breakfast I have tried the Fruit Waffles (MMM so delicious and fresh) as well as the Brulee Grapefruit (simple but now my favorite menu item). On another Sunday just after they stopped serving breakfast, my friend and I ordered their flatbreads. I had the Seasonal Flatbread ($6.95) which had asparagus, mozzarella, and olive oil. Simple and tasty! Perfect coffee shop foods, along with their salads and sandwiches. They serve generous portions of everything, which is awesome. 

Cute decor, great music, friendly service, and a cool Castro vibe. The line moves pretty fast since their beverage and food options are conveniently posted and easily located as you are waiting in line. I especially love the little signs on each table that say "Hi! Please join me at this table." It's the little things, right?
author: Stefanie C.

description:
My friend has enjoyed this place so I decided to finally check this place out. Figured I should support some local restaurant especially places with good food and coffee. 

The first time I went I got the avocado toast with a fried egg on top. Delicious! I know it's something I can make at home myself but it was reasonably priced and something healthy. I also got the black iced tea which was great for the warm days in SF. 

I've also gotten the prosciutto and poached egg, bruleed grapefruit, and the cheddar biscuit. I'll definitely say I'm in love with a biscuit.  

Delicious food and very enjoyable.  People are nice and a great area to hang out (inside or out) and grab some great food. 

Protip: find a place to sit and grab some food.
author: Nina Y.

description:
Orange juice too sweet ("squeezed in place and we add no sugar" yeah right!) espresso to sour, no wifi! No reception of LTE.

OVER PRICED, OVER PRICED, OVER PRICED!!!!!
author: Avi J.

description: The selection of brunch items, teas, coffees is simple and exquisite. Plenty of indoor and patio seating.
author: Grey L.

description:
Of course being the coffee addict I am, this is one of my favorite places to hit up when I'm around the Castro (Aside from Philz, of course)! 

While the entrance to this quiet and intimate cafe can be easily walked past, look out for the wide entrance and people lounging in their outside seating, plus you can't miss their deliciously inviting aroma! Once you enter, you'll realize how simple their place and menu are, yet it still feels very cozy and comfortable inside without ever feeling cramped or hot. 

Their service is very friendly and fast, allowing me to grab my perfectly crafted drink before I even finish paying! Next time I'll definitely come back to try one of their enticing brunch toasts I keep seeing everyone relaxing inside eat!

This place is the perfect stop along 18th to or from Dolores Park, and I always make an effort to pop my head in and I never leave disappointed!
author: Kyrie S.

description: Love this place!! Delicious coffee and food and the staff was very friendly. Will be back next time I'm in the city. There are such beautiful people there too.
author: Monica W.

description:
Out of all the coffee shops I've been to in San Fran, Reveille has to be my ultimate favorite. At first, I fell in love with the modern design, then I shortly fell in love with the coffee and pastries (the most important part!). Located on 18th in the heart of The Castro, Reveille offers a variety of pastries, toasts, waffles, eggs, coffee and more. 

The staff is extemely helpful and nice and there is ample seating inside and out. Looks can be decieving from the photos online... they don't give any justice to how big the space is inside. We opted to sit at the hightop counters that divide the counter from wall/booth seating... if you don't mind being close to others, this is a perfect spot.

Their cappuccinos & pour over coffee were divine, but I just couldn't get over the pastries. We ordered a Kouign Amann, which is essentially a cronut on crack and a biscuit with jam (homemade deliciousness). Even though I was a bit full from snacking on these items, I could have easily ordered another to go. They have 3 locations, I think the other two are in the "city". If I'm ever back in SF I will make an effort to check out the other locations... I miss everything about this place and highly sugest to all coffee & pastry lovers out there. Enjoy!
author: Juanita D.

description: If you're going to eat and work on the internet try durning the week or go somewhere else. Decors amazing, great atmosphere, food looks good, wanted something fruity so I ordered the hibiscus mint tea.... that just taste like mint, wouldn't recommend. I gave it only three stars bc I came there to be able to work and eat. But they turn off their internet on the weekends. I asked them if I could use it and they replied with you can try if we didn't already turn it off. Unfortunate they couldn't turn it on for me when. Not really interested in coming back bc of I just find that to be poor customer service. I wish I could have just returned my order and go somewhere else
author: Paige E.

description:
Cute coffee shop in the Castro.

They offer a decent selection of coffee beverages and a clean space, although in my opinion can be a bit dark on the inside. Staff is very friendly and welcoming. If you plan to study here, come early or wait out. All the seats fill up quickly. I always come here for the good coffee and decent looking baristas :P

Park further down the street, parking in front is rare to find.
author: Brian L.

description: Definitely a go-to place for people looking to hook up and have coffee in the Castro. $5 drinks which may come with some coffee art. No free wi-fi on weekends (probably to discourage idlers taking up tables). Good luck finding parking.
author: Gerald C.

description:
In addition to their great coffee I love that they have a full kitchen with an excellent menu offering up very nice options that I've ever seen in a coffee shop. The gruyere, kale, bacon and egg sandwich is particularly satisfying and is now my ideal breakfast sandwich. The avocado toast was also very nice.

I felt like we stepped into some cafe somewhere in Scandinavia. The inside decor had a slight retro vibe and the outdoor seating offers a nice hangout spot; perfect for people watching whether sunny or gloomy out. Also the staff are quick and efficient to boot. 

A great addition to the neighborhood.
author: Esther A.

description:
A small, busy, but clean space to work or catch up over coffee in the Castro.

I had this placed bookmarked, and found myself near enough to try. The outside was bustling with customers who had just picked up their coffee and were either talking to their friends or headed off for the day. At 4pm on Sunday, this place wasn't too busy and seemed only 2/3 full.

Service:
The barista was friendly and very prompt at taking and placing my order. The drinks took some time to come out, but not terribly long.

Space:
Your basic wood + white decor. Having some clean watercolor art framed along the walls gives it a nice, homier feel.

Drinks:
I ordered an herbal tea, and the person I was with ordered a mocha. While I loved my herbal tea , I wasn't a big fan of the strong coffee taste in the latter. Perhaps it's my undying love for chocolate, but there could have a been greater balance between the two flavors. One note: the barista wasn't able to fully explain the ingredients in the herbal tea. I'm not really sketched out by them or anything, I just wish they had a better explanation than, "Oh yeah... it's... grassy?" (Still highly recommend though!)

Extras:
You'll have to ask the barista for the WiFi password!

The menu for food doesn't seem very extensive, but I might try some of the savory items in the future. I won't go out of my way to return here, but it isn't a bad option at all. 3.5 stars rated up.
author: Kat P.

description: Surprised by how much I liked this place, since I'm beginning to shy away from the "hip" coffee places, because they tend to feel too sterile and get too loud. But I really liked this places vibe--dim lighting, aesthetic interior, moody electronic playing. Good coffee of course, and the coconut chia pudding was also really good--just coconut, almond milk, chia seeds, berries, and cocoa nibs, so didn't have the over-sweetness that you usually get with "healthy" desserts. Good wifi.
author: Michelle C.

description: Reveille's coffee is decent at most! The staff here is oddly pretentious, cold, and unwelcoming. It's a shame that their food menu is delicious! I often get salads here. Difficult to find healthy salads elsewhere in the Castro. Unfortunately, the coffee shop across the street closed, so I come here by default while doing laundry. I guess Starbucks is another choice.
author: John Philip B.

description:
5 stars for cold brew so yummy
1 star for the sad imitation of avocado toast + poached egg that cost $6.50 and made my heart cry. The avocado barely hung on to the disappointingly thin piece of toast.

Cute space. Most people in workout clothes on a Sat morning.
author: Carolyn F.

description:
This is, hands down, The Best Coffee In The Castro!!!

I say this having tried coffee from every other coffee shop in the neighborhood...There are other good places, but this is The Best.

The lattes are creamy, rich, fruity, and never bitter...just perfect!  

The baristas are friendly, fun, and go out of their way to be helpful, which really makes a difference to me as a customer.  For example, they aren't afraid to bring your coffee to you, if you are in a wheelchair...believe me when I say that's a rarity in this city!!

Speaking of which, Reveille is fully WHEELCHAIR-ACCESSIBLE...by which I mean that not only is this cafe set up to be wheelchair accessible, but it actually is in practice, too, because there aren't tables and chairs always blocking access.  And there's a good bathroom.  That's right, y'all.

Unlike many of the other more hipster coffee joints in the city these days, Reveille has FREE WI-FI and no maximum-sitting-time.  They serve food, too, in case you're hungry.  I've only tried the plain cheese flatbread, and while it was tasty, I was surprised to find that it was spicy, as though there might be an ample amount of something like white pepper or possibly chili oil on it...This was not mentioned on the menu, and I wouldn't have ordered it if it had been, since I'm a wimp when it comes to spice!

The outdoor patio area is quite possibly my favorite people-watching place in the city, as it is slightly set back from the sidewalk, and therefore protected from the various degrees of cray-cray that one can encounter walking by!  

Drink a lot of coffee?  They have a frequent coffee drinker punch card...Nice!

The only thing I would change about this coffee joint?  I wish it would stay open later than 8 pm!  Ahhh, c'est la vie, you can't have everything in life!!
author: Amy L.

description: I paid $5.25 for a pour over that took 10 minutes and was halfway to lukewarm. It did taste good.
author: Alan E.

description:
This Reveille makes up for my "meh" reactions to the North Beach location. The couple times I've been to its "O.G." store on Columbus, I've walked away with a humdrum reaction. Even before you walk in, the Castro shop exudes warmth and welcome. I recently dropped in and saw all these "happy, peppy people" (I sound like Lucille Ball) sitting outside sipping coffee and nibbling on toast. I figured, "This has gotta be a good sign."

I entered Reveille and immediately noticed the charming interior. Funky patterns, interesting prints (very West Elm-ish), light furnishings, and an open layout (albeit a somewhat low ceiling) make for a pleasant cafe experience. Not to keep bringing it back to their North Beach location, but... there, though they are surrounded by windows on a corner and the ceilings are high, the Columbus store is incredibly hot because of poor ventilation... not to mention the awkward shape to that store. The Castro location has a better and clearer set-up and plenty of fresh air shooting into the store thanks to a big open entrance. 

I recently had their chai latte ($4). It was tasty, spicy, and not too sweet. The baristas are friendly and maintain the cafe well. There is a small selection of newspapers for reading (I love that! I personally will always be loyal to print.). I will note that the place gets quite busy during lunch hour. I recently stopped by on a weekday around 11, and by Noon, it was crowded. I would also advise lunch-goers that this isn't the place for a quick bite. It appeared most folks' food took some time to come out, but they did look very appetizing. I'll have to come back to try some of their dishes some time. 

Overall, I'm impressed and pleased by this Reveille location. Whether you want to relax with a newspaper and a latte or catch up with friends over a light meal, this appears to be the new "hot spot" in the Castro.
author: James Z.

description:
I came here on the weekend a little after 11AM hoping to relax with some reading and a good cup of coffee.  I had no intentions of going inside since I always seemed to not notice it while walking in Castro.  It was pretty much chance that I saw this little shop wedged in the gayborhood.

All the seats were taken outside and when I got inside there was a lot of hustle and bustle.  Definitely a busy coffee shop.  Lots of gossip and "what happened last night?"-'s.  Anyhow, they have a very kempt and fresh staff.  Handsome, cute, etc.  I'm here for coffee though.

Inside, it was pretty compact.  Every chair and table was taken but there was an empty seat on the community table.  It had a pretty modern, sophisticated feel.  The black and white patterns were complimented with light stained hardwood.  I felt like I was in an open house for a fancy but affordable apartment that all of San Francisco had to go to.  Loved the overall design of the establishment.

They struck conversation with every customer; usually short and sweet but the customer in front of me had a pretty involved one.  I was mildly jealous that I wasn't part of it.  Though when I did end up ordering my coffee, we had at least a brief, warm, and welcoming exchange.  Hi-5 on the customer service.  I did not order any food and I felt a little too self conscious to order the chocolate chip cookie.  Kept thinking that everyone was saying, "he's going to order coffee AND a chocolate chip cookie?"  Eye roll.  I decided to only order the coffee.

Coffee was a delicious brew from Heaven.  I just about set myself up in the perfect position to enjoy my book.  However, it was impossible to read in that cafe.  It was loud.  Very loud.  I constantly had FOMO feelings that I missed something important from all discussions around me.  I left after reading 2 pages.  Maybe I came at an impossibly busy time?  The pictures uploaded here seem to show a less crowded space.

Overall, yes, I will come here again; but with +1 or +2 to save face.  You will have a good time with friends and possibly meet a new group of people to share stories.  I do hope to try the food next time.
author: Jared F.

description: My favorite coffee shop in SF! I love their environment, decor, amazing coffee and delicious food. I'm usually picky about coffee but this place just has the best beans! I got an almond milk latte and couldn't stop drinking it. For brunch, I ordered their breakfast sandwich which is the best breakfast sandwich that I've ever had! Not too oily and extremely flavorful. Their egg is on top of the sandwich! They also have brûlée grapefruit which was super refreshing and topped with candied kumquat (amazing!!). Definitely my go to spot in SF
author: Erica C.

description: Great coffee and amazing salads and sandwiches. We've lived in Castro 7 years, and this is definitely one of our favorite spots to open in the neighborhood!
author: Rachel G.

description:
Réveille combines my two loves in SF: coffee and The Castro.  Modern, clean with friendly service and solid coffee.  I didn't try any of their food goodies, but just a plain old Americano while my Italian friend chose an espresso.  

The name is apropos... waking up on a Saturday certainly doesn't suck with Réveille.
author: Hiromi N.

description: Great coffee, excellent and friendly service.  The food is quite good as well.  My favorite is the avocado toast with an egg on top.
author: Larry R.

description:
Really cute place in Castro! I'm surprised the Starbucks next door gets as much business as it does when Reveille is right there. It's a pretty small place - if you're walking quickly, you'll easily pass right by this place. There's a beautiful sitting area just in front of the entrance that I'd love to enjoy a book at. It's also doggy-heaven here, inside and outside, so bring your furry friends!

No wi-fi on the weekends, so really do bring a book. The iced vanilla latte was decent and at SF price (AKA expensive). However, I'd come back just for the ambience/atmosphere!
author: Stella A.

description: Nice little cafe to the side of Castro, I love the seats outside and the clean, minimalistic decor. Cool that they're open so early, and with wifi of course. But it's weird that you can't use their outlets to charge your phones/laptops so this was a minus for me. Also the wifi password cracks me up every time.
author: Katherine W.

description: This was a very spacious place to grab a nice cup of coffee and a light breakfast. The avocado toast and egg sandwich were very good.
author: Jen G.

description: This place abounds with potential. Great location. But must we have techno music pumped into our faces? Should we have to shout to hear each other in a neighborhood coffee shop? And with network reception being consistently weak inside the shop, it's kind of important that wifi be made available. But it is turned off on the weekends. Hence the emptiness of the place today, Saturday. These days, I feel like if I'm going to spend over $20 on coffee, oj, and some food, wifi should be available so that I can sit and get a bit of work in while I eat. Kinda strange. Good spot during the week. Average food. But disappointed today.
author: Ed S.

description: Came here while visiting from out of town. My boyfriend and I both got the egg sandwich and both thought it was delicious. The sauce was so delicious, and really makes it stand out from other sandwiches. It was the perfect place to grab a quick breakfast while staying nearby. If I'm ever back, I'll certainly try this place again.
author: Elizabeth T.

description: A cute little cafe in Castro! The cold brew is solid here and there's a good amount of seating. When I was here though, it was a little warm... I don't think they have a/c? So it's probably not the best choice to go to spend a day getting work done on a hot day...
author: Janet H.

description: Went to get some work done. The music inside was pretty loud, but the shadowed patio and the coffee were optimal. Nice avocado toast with the perfect touch of olive oil.
author: Riccardo F.

description: Good place to meet someone or get work done. Medium sized place with indoor and outdoor seating. Cafe hipster vibe. Order at the counter, and they bring the food to you. They have the usual cafe drinks with some brunch/ lunch food options, as well. Avocado toast is a popular item. Ah toast- 'tis thee overpriced rage these days.
author: Joanna L.

description: Absolutely sublime - homemade (not too sweet compote/jam) slathered on a freshly cooked, buttery biscuit. Shoot me!! Soooooo good.
author: Leslie L.

description: Ok, I like this place buuuuuut they only have two outlets! I just moved to this part of neighborhood and really needed to use the internet for work purposes. Soooo remember to charge your laptops!
author: Yvonne O.

description:
