Here a muscle bear, there a muscle bear. . . everywhere a muscle bear. . . Want to be able to actually sit at a nice little outdoor counter instead of being crammed inside the Country Bear Jamboree a couple doors down?. . . step over here guys. It's a great atmosphere and comfortable for all.
Oh, and the coffee is great as well. . . Everyone was really friendly (duh) and they have what looked like some pretty good sandwiches and salads going on. (I was interviewing while a trolled, I mean relaxed with my coffee)...
author: Greg S.

description: Love this place! This swanky coffee shop has good coffee and food and even better vibes. Definitely one of my favorites after a ride at SoulCycle down the block.
author: Amber S.

description:
Having walked by dozens of times, I began to look for happy faces on the patio, and there they were! Bunches of them, happy people eating and drinking. That's always the best advert a biz can have, so in I went today.

Chill vibe, not over caffinated or anything like that, and the menu was interesting. And then I saw it; avocado toast, with optional egg...suddenly the air was filled with Ludwig van and I swear next time I'll take photos, but not today...gone too soon.

And with a Dirty Chai (featuring that all time fave Espresso Shot), I'm one happy fellah!

Enjoy!
author: William M.

description: So much yum, very yes! This place is super pretty, the food is great, especially the brûléed grapefruit and the avocado toast. The coffee is really good, and in my opinion, everyone who works here is really attractive. Maybe that's weird of me to say but I don't care, well done Reveille!
author: Allison H.

description: I first came here on a Thursday morning to meet a friend over a coffee. The outdoor seating has great curb appeal, especially on the rare sunny day I went. The indoor seating was rather full every minute in the 2 hours that I was there but the vibe is awesome.
author: Eduardo P.

description:
Great place. Awesome people, brilliant food and amazing music.

Definitely recommend the herbal iced tea.
author: Keshav D.

description: Hidden gem. Great coffee with even better fresh breakfast snacks. Love the avocado toast with a poached egg and the frittatas are perfect 'on the go' treats. Nice cozy comfy neighborhood spot.
author: Doug L.

description:
Located on the Castro! 

My friend and I spontaneously decided to drive up to San Francisco, and we knew we wanted to hit up at least one coffee shop whilst we were here... Unfortunately, we had decided to be spontaneous around 7:00 pm.. so most of the coffee shops were already closed by then. HOWEVER! This lovely little place was open for a little less than one more hour! The kitchen was already closed up so we were unable to try their delectable looking avocado toast with Mr. Poached Eggu on top, but we were already thankful enough that they let us sit and drink coffee in their while they cleaned up. 

I got a pour over, and it definitely hit the spot. Made me feel prepped to conquer the world. My friend got the Dirty Chai which is basically a Chai Latte with a shot of espresso! The Dirty Chai had that unique spice to it! Tasted like a hint of cayenne pepper? I'm not too sure! But it definitely added a kick to the drink. I wouldn't be able to finish it all on my own though. 

But forreal, this place is super nicely decorated inside. There is an obvious love for wood, and it made me feel very cozy and warm with my coffee. I thought the wall of timber was super appealing to the aesthetic eye! I would want a wall like that somewhere in my future home.
author: Kim N.

description:
I've been visiting Reveille regularly since they opened and the food is consistently delicious. I am very grateful to have a place with fresh greens and interesting sandwiches in the neighborhood. The orders take some time to prepare, which can be slightly anxiety inducing when on a short lunch break, but it's always worth it.

The weekday clientele knocks my rating down one star though. Maybe one of the self-absorbed  jerks manspreading at a four person table could create an app that would calculate how much food and drink he needs to purchase per hour of sitting there to make the business sustainable. How do they not understand that a cafe makes money by turning tables? Stop treating it like your live/work loft unless you are going to pay the rent. The next time i have to take my lunch to go because the place is an ibook parking lot, I might accidentally-on-purpose spill my coffee on a laptop so that at least there is one beverage on the table.

The new policy of no electrical outlets while still maintaining free wifi will surely strike the right balance.
author: Jenn H.

description:
Thanks for the excellent coffee,
With love,
Coffee snob.
author: Kristie F.

description: Cool venue in a great part of the city. Vibe is chilled and doesn't have the myriad white boys with Macbooks trying to be the next big thing in Tech that most coffee shops in the city have.
author: Mia M.

description:
I tried really hard to hate on this place because there's so much damn coffee in the Castro (and now even more) but I caved. First of all, their patio is almost always in the sun and there's a nook my mutt just loves to curl up in for sunbathing while we sip. I'm a big fan of the ice lattes and cold brew and the staff is really great. We've since been in a lot and I appreciate how they always seem to go the extra mile (even if my husband heard my order wrong and told them the wrong thing or when our ticket gets lost and there's a bit of a delay). For breakfast food you can't go wrong with the egg sandwich, the toast with egg and avocado or the perfectly crispy biscuit and jam. 

Congratulations, Reveille you won over this little hater.
author: Nikki M.

description: Delicious Haas avocado on levain toast with fried egg, salt and pepper and olive oil for the win. So simple, yet so amazing. You may think it is simple enough to recreate at home, but they are so good at making perfect toast and deciphering avocado peak ripeness. I could eat avocado toast with or without fried egg for breakfast, lunch and dinner, especially with Kayla Itsines' army of bbg girls instagramming lovely pics of avocado toast. Great coffee, too. A friend who lived in the neighborhood introduced me to this place. He knows my style, and I was definitely happy with the menu offerings, tasty food and hip setting.
author: Liv K.

description: Great spot.  Love the menu.  Downside is when you walk in and every table has one girl sitting there with a cold cup of coffee and a laptop....clearly there for hours.  Staff could be a bit friendlier.
author: Randy M.

description:
Good coffee. Kinda neat little location.  Sunny seating in the morning.  I was not a fan of the egg sandwich because it seemed greasy, but I liked that the egg wasn't scrambled.  
Prosciutto sandwich is good.
author: Chelsea D.

description:
Just as expected: excellent coffee with great service. The open-air feel of the place does not disappoint. Neither does their coffee, or the pastries, or the kind employees.

I opted for a soy latte and a chocolate kouign amman (no, it's not from B Patisserie): http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/r%C3%A9veille-coffee-co-san-francisco-6?select=FjVbqJic7vXFo9JN7X1Dgg#zGnfrj1hZ3GNVf7rpm41vw It was splendid!

With free wifi, plenty of indoor and outdoor seating, it's a nice addition to Castro. 

Welcome to the neighborhood, folks.
author: Adena B.

description: While visiting friends in the Castro my boyfriend and I checked this place out.  Everything was top notch--the coffee was delicious, my tea was excellent.  My boyfriend had the avocado toast, and I had a pastry.  We were very pleased with our order.  Like any other big city the prices are slightly on the higher end, but we felt it was still worth it.
author: Rourke S.

description:
Stopped by for a quick breakfast, loved my meal, did not know what I was ordering, but it ended up being delicious. Had a hot chocolate with a perfect temperature of milk! The outside is so beautiful!
Amazing spot
author: Sofia K.

description: EXCELLENT COFFEE, SUPER FRIENDLY STAFF. I always feel like I'm visiting friends when getting my morning latte. Though pricey and can be a wait for your drink, it's worth it. Also is a relaxing chill environment with a nice outdoor patio area. They have WiFi and water available on the counter without getting in line. Been going for several years daily and have never once had a bad latte!
author: Darrin F.

description: Love the chai here.  Great place to sit outside and sip on your beverage of choice while people watching.
author: Sondra H.

description: Great space to spend a relaxing morning. Ordered an avocado toast with egg and a dirty chai and spent 2 lovely hours here on a weekday morning (not sure how packed it gets on the weekends, but it wasn't hard to get a table when I went). Food was yummy, but not extraordinary. I've definitely made the same thing at home myself. I'd love to try their breakfast sandwich next time, though!
author: Kathy L.

description:
Didn't get to try their food - I was strictly there for their coffee.

Jaime and I were strolling around the Castro mid-afternoon when my crankiness was setting in because I hadn't had my daily caffeine fix. As we were walking around a hip little neighborhood, my nose immediate caught a whiff of espresso. The heart wanted what it wanted at that moment and it came in the form of a dirty chai.

From the outside, it's a cute little coffee shop. Inside, it's a cool little cafe with communal tables and some pretty delicious looking food. Having just finished a massive lunch, I needed something to keep me chipper - that's why I added an extra shot.

The process was quick, easy and the staff was friendly. Within a few minutes we were presented with our drinks and back out into the city we went.

The flavors of the chai and bold coffee flavors represented themselves well and I inhaled that beverage super quick. That's always a good sign when you reconsider going back for more or just wishing that you had ordered a larger size.

I'd definitely come back - especially for food!
author: Ryan C.

description: Great coffee (latte), friendly staff and an good atmosphere off Castro Street. Good number of tables insides, particularly if not busy during the week. Service is always fast in the morning if your on the commute.
author: K M.

description:
How can you say no to five dollar toast!?

Serious!?

San Diego is really behind the food trends these days. I'm just waiting for a toastery to open down the block so I can enjoy toasted bread all day, every day, forever. 

The toasted bread... Was it wheat? Or sourdough? Perhaps it was white bread. So exquisite. And toasted to perfection. The chef really has this skill down. Not too toasted. Not under toasted. But just right. As far as culinary delights are concerned, toast is the new bacon. Or is it the new cupcake?  Or new cronut? Whatever it is, it's nothing less than revolutionary. Thank you chefs of San Francisco!

And the coffee... So stinking good. 
And the people watching from the patio is the proverbial 'cherry on top'. What more can you ask?
author: Jade D.

description:
Great coffee stop.  Typically we stop at Philz, but opted to try something different as we live just a couple of blocks away from the Philz on 24th.  Glad we decided to do so, as their coffee and espresso was quite tasty. 

I ordered an Americano and really loved the flavor.  My husband ordered their coffee and loved the robust flavor of the beans (I believe they use Four Barrel beans, if I remember correctly).

The place has a cute atmosphere, and we made a mental note to stop back in for a casual lunch or brunch sometime.  The few menu items we saw people order looked very fresh and interesting, so we definitely will be back again to try out their food as well.
author: Rachael S.

description: Great coffee.  My friends rave about the breakfast croissants, but I have found them only so-so.  I prefer their avocado toasts or kouign amann, both of which are excellent.
author: Herb G.

description: Love this place -- cannot believe I hadn't been there before! Met the daughter for coffee on a recent Sunday and sat outside facing the street and watched the trendy world go by. Avocado toast? Sublime! The coffee is perfectly brewed with just the right amount of jolt. Great mix of people, relaxed feel - what more can you ask on a chilly Sunday. And yes - you can bitch about the parking, but I found a spot just around the corner (a miracle, I know) and after all, it's our lot in life living here isn't it? This will be one of my new go-to spots in SF!
author: Lisa W.

description:
5-stars for their chocolate chip cookie. It was soft and gooey and super delicious. Four days later, I'm still thinking about it!

Overall, very friendly and relaxing cafe. It was perfect to just hang out there, drink a coffee and eat a cookie. The Chai Latte wasn't the best I've had, too spicy for my taste, but some people like it that way. The Hot Chocolate was much better!

We'll be back!
author: Malin D.

description: I was walking by this location and the decor drew me in. I received excellent service from the order taking to the quality of the food. I had the egg sandwich and a latte. The freshness and taste were great. I look forward to going again soon.
author: Luis C.

description:
Delicious espresso!  Best coffee in the Castro. It's a cool converted garage with wood benches in the former driveway.  Able to bring my dog.  :)
The BLAT (BLT with apple and avocado) is yummy albeit pricey, but everything in SF is expensive.
author: Jamey F.

description:
New coffee shop in the Castro. Coffee is excellent. Tasty, yum. 
Decoration is nice and pleasant. 
On the downside, the coffee cups to go only come in two sizes... Small, which is really small and Large, which is more like a medium...
Tables are mostly occupied by only one person and a laptop. So its difficult to sit by yourself and enjoy your food, which by the way, is not that terrible. Music is very loud. 
I recommend sitting on the front patio and enjoy the scene.
author: Gabriel G.

description:
Cute little indie coffee shop. Not being a bear, the Starbucks two doors down always makes me feel a little 'fish out of water', not being particularly hirsute or obese. It's nice to have a nicer option.

A bit pricey, but not really out-of-line with other indie coffee shops in the area.
author: Sean B.

description: A very cosy place! Their vegetarian sandwich made my day and the service was really nice, too.
author: Aleksandra Ć.

description: My favorite hang out spot in the Castro! Staff are pretty friendly once you get to talk to them longer. There's usually a line, but I've never had to wait more than 5 minutes for someone to get my order. The atmosphere is pretty relaxed and the drinks are very affordable. I would not want to recommend this place just because I don't want more people to come.
author: Sebastian G.

description: One of the top roasters in town. Coffee so good I usually drink it black. Finding a seat can be tough at times in a sea of laptops but that's the way it goes when a place is this good.
author: John W.

description: Great coffee, nice place. I could work from there all the time if only the music wasn't far too loud to focus
author: Celia G.

description:
Love the coffee shop, hate the coffee. 

the space is bright and modern with outdoor seating. Perfect place to catch up with a friend, study, work on a project, etc.  I loved the ambiance.

I ordered an espresso and it was so bitter that it was sour. and I grew up drinking espressos. Either way, I'll likely be back if I'm in this neighborhood because it's just such a delightful location!
author: Alice Z.

description: Came here to work one day when my internet was out, and I'll definitely come back. The vibe is super hip, coffee is delicious, Internet is fast, and I had one of the best chocolate chip cookies I've ever tasted here. The seating is a tad bit uncomfortable for a coffee shop, but there is plenty of it. I want to go back and try some more of their food.
author: Karen D.

description: Reveille Coffee is my favorite cafe in San Francisco. The latte is one of the best in the city (definitely on par with a Blue Bottle, Four Barrels, etc.) and it comes without attitude from friendly staff. The atmosphere of the cafe is quaint both indoors and the front patio outdoors. The food is delicious. During the week there's free wifi; however, there are no outlets to plug in.
author: Carol N.

description:
I was inspired to stop by Réveille Coffee Co. after an espresso review of SF done by BuzzFeed (The Taste Buds reviewed 'Espresso A-Go-Go In San Francisco Co. 2k15!'). 

The café is unobtrusive and outwardly unremarkable - In my search for the café, I walked by Réveille twice without noticing. The interior had a clean and geometric feel to it. Despite the off-peak timing, most seats were occupied, so I felt fortunate to snag a seat at the café bar. 

I ordered my espresso and took my seat. Unfortunately, despite the lull in clientele, the staff somehow forgot to make my espresso. After ten minutes, I had to remind them that I had not received my order. 

My espresso was served alongside a glass of carbonated water and a spoon (I appreciate not having to ask for these items). The espresso itself was good. It had bold flavour and good crema. Espresso lovers that are partial to high acidity will love the espresso here - those who prefer milder espresso (or those with perhaps more delicate palates) may not like Réveille's espresso. 

My experience here was okay - their espresso is pretty good, but I was disappointed in the inattentive customer service. Comparable espresso is abundant in the area, so I am likely to visit a different cafe with better attention and service to patrons. 

Verdict:
Somewhat disappointing. I probably would not revisit this establishment.
author: Laila A.

description:
Perfect little meal + coffee after Sunday morning Farmer's Market.

Great cappuccino - and the barista was super nice.

Also had the avocado toast + fried egg. The egg was cooked perfectly. Priced perfectly as well. 

Like the vibe of the place, the decor is friendly/warm, and the seating lovely. We sat at the counter, and had a warm snack.
author: Amy O.

description:
The coffee, pastries and food at Reveille are actually decent, especially for the Castro.

The reason for me so-so review is the atmosphere. When I take a break from work and head out for breakfast or a coffee, the LAST thing I want to see is a crowd of people on their laptops, and that's pretty much all one finds at Reveille. Call me old fashioned, but staring at my OWN screen for 12 hours a day is enough. I don't need to see everyone else's, or hear their business conversations. It's always impossible to get a seat as the crowd settles in with their laptops and STAYS. Hey good for them. Not so good for me.

So yes- fine coffee and all that, but I'd rather head to Thoroughbread on Church for their amazing scones, or up to Peet's on Market for just coffee. Or even Four Barrel if I'm feeling trendy.

One note on the food- Reveille's Shakshuka is tasty but it's not really Shakshuka. It's more of a Mexican version. Spicy and good, but not the real thing.

I did quite like the Avocado toast. But count me out as long as the laptops reign supreme.
author: Carl M.

description: They turn the wifi off on the weekends, because "it gets too busy." I would not be writing a bad review if they had kick ass coffee, but their cold brew sucks also. So help them cut down on the traffic in-store I will not be returning to this basic coffee shop.
author: Keaton S.

description: Awesome ambiance, awesome coffee, awesome food, awesome people. Really great place for those looking for somewhere to get work done, but get here early as all the spots-though numerous- get snagged fast. Also, there is an outdoor, greenery-coveree patio where you and your dog can enjoy the space!
author: Cassie P.

description: Reveille is such a cute coffee shop!  Upon entering, their space is welcoming, homey, modern, and clean all at the same time.  I ordered a mocha to go and it came flavored perfect.....not as hot as I usually like it, but good nonetheless.  They have indoor seating as well as outdoor seating and I LOVE the music they play.  I would return on the music alone.  Yes I know you don't go to coffee shops to listen to music, but you know you like a place when you go and you're just feelin it....singing along to the songs.  Do I ever get that happy visiting a Starbucks?  I think not.
author: Christine D.

description:
This place is good, has a nice atmosphere, but I'm not crazy about it. The prices threw me off. I had one of their grapefruit dishes where they use a torch to roast the top of the two grapefruit halves - it was pretty tasty but the price was over the top. My wife had one of their power bowl style quinoa/pomegranate (I think) bowls. She liked it. Cappuccino was good.

Overall, it was good but we spent as much money on a very tiny breakfast as we do on lunch...
author: Ian S.

description: Coffees and teas are fine . It's pretty expensive which is expected  . If you are the one who would spend time in the coffee shop reading books or working or even talking to your friends , you can't sit here for a considerable amount of time. They are sly enough to reduce the temperature in here or open the doors so that it gets cold enough that you would decide to move out !
author: Ganesh R.

description: The male barista here is super racist. I asked him for wifi password and he said there's no wifi in the store. The weirdest thing is everyone inside the store is using their laptop to check FB and IG. Finally we found wifi password by ourselves. Will I visit here again? Definitely NO!!!!!
author: Ryan L.

description: My new coffee shop in SF. Well made, good tasting coffee. I especially love their vanilla latte and avocado toast. Friendly baristas work on your coffee. Well apointed shop with inside and outsude seating areas. Recommended!
author: Steff T.

description: Stopped here for a quick cup of coffee while walking around the Castro area. Having already had a latte earlier in the day, I decided to go for a cold brew. It was a tad bitter for my taste, but cold brew usually is, and somehow I always forget this. The coffee shop itself was really awesome, and the environment was pretty laid back for the most part. There was some outdoor seating that we grabbed, since we had a dog with us. Quietly chatting, the person next to us started giving us looks and putting his fingers over his ears to show his annoyance with us. That was my only qualm with the place. The food all looked really tasty, but I was pretty full at this point. I definitely suggest checking out this spot! Seems like a great place to relax or do work, if needed.
author: Dayna R.

description: Really nice coffee shop with nice baristas. Legit quality coffee but just a little noisy.
author: Yushi C.

description:
"Do you guys do drips ?"

"Noo .. uh .. we just have them because they're pretty"

Ok, I meant do you have options, just one coffee, a menu.. what's the procedure ?

Also my friend wanted to charge her phone for 5 minutes, from one of the clearly visible outlet and was told "honey, this is not going to happen".

I get it, you're too pretty to be serving coffee. But you don't have to take it out on us.
author: Matthieu T.

description:
I've been here a couple of times. 
I really like their coffee and it's a very comfortable space to hang out, relax and drink the coffee.  Great location too. Definitely recommend checking this cafe out.
author: Eleanor L.

description: Fell in love with the cold brew and biscuits. Great place to sit and work and people watch til the laptop battery runs out.
author: Kate F.

description:
I really enjoyed this space. I've been here a couple times and am always impressed with the calm customer service from the staff. During this visit their was a nice woman behind the counter who clearly cared about the beverages she was making and took care in pride in her service. 

I ordered an ice tea and was very happy. It's not cheap iced tea that often has a bitter taste but flavorful and kept me satiated. 

The atmosphere was pleasant and the interior design was on point. It also wasn't very loud which is often a deterrent for me. I'll definitely be coming back here.
author: Christopher S.

description: One of my favorite cafes. Never crowded, has wifi, serves EXCELLENT sandwiches, excellent granola and yogurt, AND has a great environment for working. I have a big soft spot for this place.. It is a smaller space but I've always been able to sit myself there without waiting. There's also tea, served in a glass pot. I adore this cafe, I hope it doesn't ever turn into an overcrowded place, I think it's a better fit for a slow routine.
author: Kathy Z.

description: Food is overpriced. Coffee is good but be ready to wait at least 10 minute for it.
author: E T.

description:
Their coffee is phenomenal. I came here twice and the coffee is just really really well brewed. 

The only downside is the no-wifi policy on weekend. I think that sucks. I didn't eat lunch here because of that.
author: Dan P.

description: Amazing macchiato in the Castro! The service was very friendly and they grind the coffee in house. Me and my wife had amazing coffee here. If your in the Castro consider a coffee in this joint.
author: Emmanuel R.

description:
So lucky me when I saw the SFist's best breakfast sandwich list (http://sfist.com/2014/02/26/the_best_breakfast_sandwiches_and_b.php) and one of the items on the list was at the new Réveille Coffee down the street from me. 

For clarification, even though the 18th St location isn't listed on their website, it's there, it's open and it has the exact same menu. Breakfast until 11:30 but you can get takeaway and essentially make the breakfast sandwich your lunch, as I did because I can't ever get up early enough to have that big of a breakfast followed by a lunch.

The sandwich is the first one on the menu - Egg Sandwich w/ Bacon (fried egg, braised kale + leek, and gruyere on Della Fattoria levain). There are two prices $7.50 (egg sandwich) and $9 (w/ bacon). Not as apparent as they might have thought because I had to ask. 

I have to admit, when I opened the takeaway box and saw a plain looking sandwich I was a little disappointed. It just looked so plain. It looks exactly like the photos so I didn't feel tricked, I think I just wasn't paying attention. However one bite and my mind was blown. Such attention to detail really made an amazing sandwich. #1 - the slices of bread were toasted/grilled with butter/olive oil on both sides before being assembled into a sandwich. #2 - the bacon was perfectly cooked to crispy without being burnt. #3 - they use some quality gruyere because it had a whiff of that stinky funky cheese smell. I kept sniffing like what's that smell then realized it was the cheese. #4 - the cheese was melted into the kale and leeks while the bacon was kept crispy. And of course #5 - a soft cooked egg in a hole on top.

Seriously good breakfast sandwich and it's so close to me! I'd put it up right up there with my other favorite breakfast sandwich at Devil's Teeth Baking.

PS This is a small place and by the time i showed up at 11:15 all the tables were taken with (surprise surprise) people on laptops leaving just the outside tables and inside bar free. Though that's fine with me it felt a little weird to be the only person eating there so I got mine to go.
author: Jean K.

description: A supremely dry and stale bacon cheddar biscuit and coffee cake, very ok coffee and rather unwilling to serve 'servers' all for 17 dollars. Nope, never coming back here!
author: Roma T.

description: Sadly, they no longer have wifi on the weekends, which is disappointing. I don't stay long after I finish my coffee and sandwich, but maybe other people were. Even without a laptop, the wifi was necessary to use my phone, because it's hard to get a cell signal in the Castro. I'll still go weekday mornings before work, but looks like I will need to find another place to go on the weekends.
author: Bryan M.

description: This is my second coffee shop visit in the Castro so I don't know much about the alternatives, but compared to NYC, this cafe was great, and the service was straight forward but polite. Prices reflect the area and I adore the outdoor seating area in front. If you can get a seat, it seems like a great place to break during the day!
author: Morgen B.

description: Great orange juice, great food, i was able to find a table pretty easily, it was generally a super nice vibe.
author: M T.

description: Fantastic food, fantastic coffee, fantastic service! This place is just fantastic! I highly recommend the lattes and the kale salad with turkey.
author: Cloud G.

description: Had the blap sandwich! Dunno how a bunch of basic ingredients made such a yummy sandwich but it happened! Side salad was good too!
author: Monika L.

description: One of the best lattes I've ever had in my life!!! No more Starbucks for me! It also has a very cool relaxed atmosphere.
author: RD R.

description: Service is pretty quick, and gladly they serve coffee right away as you wait for your food. Cute venue.
author: Ameryl L.

description: Horrible places. I feel like I am being discriminated being non-white and all. The service is slow and unfriendly. No matter how hip this place pretends to be, it can't be more non-welcoming
author: Ken C.

description:
Great ambiance, helped by the fact we were able to land a sunny table outside. Indoors seemed a little claustrophobic... some might consider cosy. Had the BLAP sandwich, with the A and the P accounting for ripe Avocado and Pear on a perfectly toasted levain with creamy citrus aioli. Nicely-dressed simple salad with radish accompanied the sandwich, including a sparkling water made for a $12 lunch.

My only complaint was the sole food menu placed on a small stand next to the cashier which forced each customer to hover behind the person in front of them. Just one more on the island table in the middle of the cafe wouldn't kill the cool and clean aesthetic.
author: Jake H.

description: Had their avocado toast on acme levian and hot cocoa. I search endlessly for the perfect hot chocolate and I believe my search has ended. Love the cute sit out area. Would highly recommend this place
author: Vasini G.

description:
The space itself is awesome - the inside is cozy with a small outdoor area right by the door. The low rating is for the coffee drinks. I ordered lattes the two times I've been here and both times I ordered them extra hot, only to receive a barely-luke-warm drink. My friend's drink ended up being worse - borderline cold. I think it depends on the barista working at the time, but at this price point, I'd expect a little more. 
The second time I was here, my friend and I threw away our drinks and went to the Castro Center next door to finally get what we wanted - some hot caffeine on a cold day.
author: Patricia L.

description: I stumbled upon this coffee shop while walking around the Castro District. What a lovely place with beautiful decor and amazing coffee. I stayed there for a while reading my book, and I will definitely go back on my next visit to San Francisco.
author: Julia R.

description: Was bummed that I didn't make it in time for the egg breakfast sandwich, so I settled with the turkey sandwich which was delicious! It also comes with a side of green with this lemony dressing that I loved. I also had the cappuccino, but it was nothing special.
author: Yanni C.

description: I had the Guatemala retan roast coffee. It was sweeter than I anticipated but tasty. I also had the almond croissant and bacon biscuit. The almond croissant crushed the bacon biscuit. They would benefit from warming up the biscuits or at least offering the service. The cost is the main reason for losing the 5th star. $13 for coffee and 2 pastry's. Highlight of the experience was the almond croissant.
author: Ryan O.

description: It has a lovely entrance. I had the vegetarian sandwich, which was great. I wished the tea pot was bigger though. There's also free wifi.
author: Azer K.

description: I was looking for a cafe to work on a Sunday. Unfortunately, after I ordered a drink, there's no wifi during the weekend. I felt they do not welcome people working in their cafe and sitting too long.
author: Meiteng L.

description: Consistently great espresso, one of my fave places to go sit outside and soak up the sun while a nonstop parade of people accost our dog and ask us what breed he is (a mutt from the pound, who looks like a tiny chow chow crossed with arctic fox and perhaps wombat). Our locally famous wonder dog soaks up the accolades as we sit there like chopped liver, sipping delicious beverages and enjoying one of the last San Francisco neighborhoods to have any character left at all.
author: Cleo J.

description: My favorite coffee shop in the Castro for many reasons. Drinks are great, food is delicious. Most importantly, the staff is extremely friendly and inviting. I live nearby, and this is absolutely a place that I'm going to be multiple times a week for that very reason. I pay a lot of attention to the way that staff treats its customers, and am happy to say that everyone who works here is incredibly present, seems to enjoy what they're doing, and is incredibly attentive and inviting. I can't say the same for all coffee shops in the area.
author: Lillian N.

description:
I would usually go to Philz across the street because it's consistently awesome, but it is the day after Turkey death and was overpacked. I had been walking by this spot for a few months and was meaning to try it , and it didn't look too bad so I went for it.

Coffee: pretty good. 
Service: register person super friendly, barista squad I didn't like the aura I peeped on you all . 
Food: ordered the egg sandwich WITH bacon. It was 9 bucks with BACON. Shocking (not shocking) when I finally got to eating it having took it out, there was no bacon added to the sandwich.So I paid 9 bucks for two pieces of toast with the middle cut out for an egg and spinach . NOT EVEN CHEESE!Get your bs together , you're not that dope
author: Lauren V.

description: I came here with high hopes because of the raving reviews from everyone. Had the avocado, egg and a latte. Breakfast was extremely average. Can't complain about bad food but it was nothing to rave about. Sat down and there was no sugar on the table. It was put at a station that was out by the door. Then, the latte is served in a Cappuccino cup, rather than a latte glass. If this is a place that raves about its coffee and wants to be known for its coffee, then serve it right. I'd like to try the other location before coming to a final decision of whether i'd go back or not.
author: Van-Anh N.

description:
Loved my two visits to Reveille Coffee co. 

First off, the space is gorgeous! There is plenty of room to move around and the overall look is enticing. 

I had a pour over and the avocado toast and both were incredible. I was a little sad that I couldn't just sit there all day because I probably would have. Dog and people friendly. The service was great and everyone was upbeat for an early Monday morning. 

I came in the second time and have a cappuccino (wonderful) and an almond croissant. I am very picky when it comes to coffee and baked goods, and although the croissant didn't have too much flakiness to it and was a little too moist, the taste was overall very good.
author: Lexi M.

description: On our trip to San Francisco in November, we tried Reveille Coffee Co. It was our last day in the City so this was our last stop on the way to the airport. It was pouring that morning so before we headed to the airport we wanted warm coffee and breakfast. With packed bags we show up to Reveille Coffee and it did not disappoint. This place was cozy and warm. Their egg sandwich and mocha were delicious. So glad we got to try it before we left. Give them a try if you are in the area.
author: Angelie S.

description: Coffee good, lackadaisical staff and inability to move faster then a snail, horrible.  If you can't make coffee and talk shut up.
author: Heith M.

description:
I have been to the Castro location a few times and the staff has always been friendly. It is located in the downstairs of a building with a little front patio overlooking 18th Street. 

The latte has pretty latte art but the coffee is too acidic for my liking. Have tried latte on a few occasions and the coffee is acidic. Food is the highlights at Reveille. Simple and healthy. I like the avocado toast and the "egg-in-a-hole" breakfast open-face sandwich.  

Ambiance is great. Relaxing and comfy, but laptop people hog up most of the tables. I would come here early before they get there and enjoy the morning.
author: Matt Y.

description: Great coffee and food, I only wish they had a bit more seating available. It definitely seems like a place where people just come by and occupy the seating for hours.  But the coffee and food are great.  The baristas really seem to know what they're doing.  The food here is great, they have an amazing breakfast sandwich with an egg cooked into the bread, it'd definitely worth trying.  Though they do have some quick pastries to go here, they often times seem to run out of these so don't expect to really find any in the evening.
author: Bryson L.

description:
The food, coffee and ambiance here are great. I especially love the kale salad - nice flavors and very filling. Free wi-fi and nice outdoor seating. 

The first time I came here, would have rated it 5 stars. BUT on a re-visit they messed up my food order, and when I politely asked the lady who was working to fix it, she gave me some major attitude. Wowwwwww. First she tried to convince me I was wrong, then when she realized I was right, she gave me a nasty look and asked if I still wanted them to fix it. Um, yes? I will say that the other guys working were really nice. Maybe someone had a case of the Mondays.
author: Monica O.

description: I love eggs so I went to Reveille to try the famous breakfast sandwich. I didn't like it very much.  I also had an iced tea which I paid $4 for (realized what the price was too late) .The price/value is low and although the environment of the cafe is cool I will not go back.
author: Flora F.

description:
Delicious artfully prepared, but pricey food and coffee, lattes.

My only complaint when I sit down for nice quiet brunch I don't think Sid Vicious music is exactly what I would select.
author: Jeffrey G.

description:
Great coffee and breakfast items.  A little warm inside during the summer and a canopy over the patio would be more than welcome.
Nice addition to the Castro.
author: Bob H.

description: Great coffee shop. Delicious breakfast. Lovely outdoor seating.
author: Megan B.

description: The cappuccino was exactly what I expected a good cappuccino to smell and taste like.
author: Elvin Y.

description: Traditional espresso with a taste that differs slightly from the other SF coffee giants. It's a great spot with a super cool interior and delicious coffee.
author: Eman A.

description:
I cannot express how happy I am that this place moved into our neighborhood. Great atmosphere, coffee, and food. Some quick reviews of specific items:
- Breakfast sandwich - great but the kale makes it taste too healthy for me
- Waffle - So much butter but also so delicious. I felt like I might have taken a few weeks off my life but it was also worth it.
- Quinoa Salad - Delicious and healthy. My go to lunch in the neighborhood as it not only tastes delicious it also leaves me feeling good about myself.
author: Ben R.

description:
I love the coffee here. Usually get a breve macchiato.

They use Four Barrel beans so their coffee is delicious.

The hot chocolate is a bit too modest for my tastes.

Also, one beef! The word is an American word with French origin, but they prefer the French pronunciation.

I think "Revili" sounds way better than "Rehvay" :P
author: Morgan K.

description:
This location isn't as good as the location as the location on Columbus; or at least the barista that served me wasn't as good as the one at the other-- which is to say the art on my cappuccino was an unflattering broken mush.

Unlike the place on Columbus, this location has wifi and people who use it. It seems to be pretty sceney; many people sit and work in the outdoor seating area as if they want to be seen. I actually kind of like the one on Columbus had no wifi, since it's somewhat unpleasant to see people working on their laptops.

I did like the wooden interior and the "Please sit with me" signs on the tables. Cool idea.
author: Ceasar B.

description:
yummy yum yum: here's an example where the pomp of hand dripped coffee pays off. It's good! And so is the food: my toast with the real-deal jam was over the moon amazing, and my girlfriend's breakfast sandwich with a perfect egg also incredible.

It's super close and sadly always crowded. Because it's GOOD!
author: Diane B.

description: The coffee here is so good that in typically hold my nose and put up with baristas who are much too cool to actually wait on you.  Today imagine my pleasant surprise when Gene and Chris turned out to be so friendly.  I'll come back again hope I luck out and get them again.
author: Bob B.

description:
This place is fantastic. The ambiance is great, the food is tasty, and the coffee delicious. 

Also the employees are all very attractive. Not complaining :)
author: Caroline C.

description:
I had the quinoa veggie salad here. It was fresh and delicious. I would totally order it again.
Great place, with wifi and places to sit
author: Billie R.

description:
I must admit that there have a been numerous times in which I would walk thirty minutes just to have their coffee and catch up with work and/or friends. If that doesn't show how much I enjoy going here, then I don't know what does.

Though it can feel a little stuffy in here and has the tendency to get progressively warm inside, they also provide a lovely outdoor patio in which you can enjoy the sun and fresh air.

They have a really great staff and that definitely helps with creating a great environment. But the empty seats fill up quite fast so if I can provide any suggestion or tip, it's to make sure you go early!
author: Armando A.

description: cool place. good vibes, good coffee. lots of people and there was a line, but it went quickly. we had the chia seed pudding and the hot cakes. definitely would go back.
author: Daniel C.

description: Hip is the last word that comes to mind whenever I think of an establishment in the Castro but that's exactly what Reveille Coffee is. A great addition to the neighborhood, Reveille offers Four Barrel coffee but really separates itself with its fantastic breakfast and lunch options. I had a Bacon and Kale Sandwich with a sunny side egg that really hit the spot. There are other options like Creme Brulee Grapefruit, Avacado Toast, and Spinach Egg Scramble which I will need to try. It's an awesome place to chill as they have bar, outdoor, and bench seating. Great music, friendly staff, and comfy interior design round up this 5 star establishment. Try it out!
author: Charlie L.

description: Ordered the dirty chai as recommended from fellow yelpers. Crazy spice bomb. Awesome flavors, yet a little on the watery side. Which it was a little bit more creamy. Decided on the peanut butter and toast to accompany it. Decent, but The Mill doesn't have anything to worry about. Considering they are both $4 save your money for the next time you are on Divis. Heard great things about the avocado and egg toast, just wasn't feeling it this morning. I may come back to try that, as it has raving reviews!
author: Victoria O.

description: Ambiance is fantastic, and if you're looking for the best pour overs and lattes in the Castro, you can't go wrong here. Great place to study, people-watch, or dog-watch. They don't have the same setup of coffee selections as philz across the street, but I think they really compliment their coffee offerings with philz.
author: Polina S.

description: their vegetarian sandwich is amazing 10/10. it has asian pear, avocado, arugula, lemon vinaigrette, candied walnuts herbed goat cheese served on Acme levain bread. I tried it for the first time today and will probably be back this week to get it again. the ambiance and energy of the cafe is amazing as well.
author: Anthony A.

description:
Good food, great drinks and a nice build out. It does get pretty crowded on the weekends since it is one of the better coffee shops/light breakfast places in the area.

I did knock off a couple stars since unfortunately they have hired a few guys with pretty nasty attitudes who are too above it all and should not be working in the service industry. Most the staff is pretty nice though and while I have never had issues myself I have seen one staff member in particular go out of his way to be rude to patrons multiple times who are mostly older and not fabulous enough apparently. Hopefully management is paying attention or this location will get a bad rep.
author: James H.

description:
My new favorite place!  I travel out of my neighborhood (DT) to get coffee here, almost every day. The baristas are friendly, playful & fun, and now know me by name + drink order, always offering a warm welcome.  I love the interior design of the space; it's well played for the space constraints (low ceiling).   Reveille is new, sparkly and always pristine inside. To that end, yesterday Allie and Jasper were cleaning baseboards and that nice patterned tile between customers when I arrived.  (Putting the baristas' names on the board up front is a great idea!) =-)

So, if this place doesn't get five stars, what do you have to be?  The Castro has really needed a cafe like this--so glad they're here now.

P.s. A person below update her review from 5- down to 4-stars because people camp out with laptops--is that fair? Would a 5-star-worthy neighborhood bar get downgraded because people like to come, stay & chat for happy hour? Protective laptop camper guy, here! =-)
author: Brian B.

description:
Kind of disappointing.   4.75 for a lukewarm cup of coffee. "It will take 5 minutes."  How can pour-over coffee take that long?

I think she was new...

No dark roast - WTF?
author: George H.

description: Great espresso drinks and the best service. Liberty behind the counter is wonderful. Thanks for making my day better whenever I stop in, Lib!
author: Jennifer W.

description:
Just started going here about a month or so ago and I'm definitely a fan so far.  My partner and I have started going here on Sunday mornings before we take our boys to the dog park (our four-legged boys, that is) and we've come to enjoy their espresso drinks and pastries.  

While I've not sat inside, so don't know if they offer plugs and wifi to make it a good work spot, it does feel cozy and comfortable inside, with a small patio area out front, which promises for good people watching.

Right now I'd say this is probably the best coffee shop in the Castro and will continue going here until they prove otherwise - especially since Peet's was acquired by some German firm and is making questionable product decisions.
author: Scott L.

description: Fantastic coffee, excellent service, good pastries (today our bread broke on its way out of the case, so it was given to us on the house), and a great layout, providing lots of seating and good flow in a relatively tiny space. Reveille draws a really good crowd too. I've always had friendly interactions and my toddler acts really at ease sitting at the banquettes, watching the crowd and munching a snack. Bonus points for being kid-friendly, and it's loud enough that little ones don't violate the vibe.
author: Quinn S.

description:
It's pretty ballsy for another coffee chain to go up against Starbucks but this coffee shop is a few doors down from a Starbucks on the Castro. As a non-coffee drinker, I wouldn't be able to comment on the coffee. I came with a friend on one of the warmer days in San Francisco and it was already busy. Unlike Starbucks, they cook food. They were switching from the breakfast menu to their lunch one which provided me with different options. I went for the Grilled cheese and liked it. It came with a salad that was so-so, but I applaud the effort. The staff was sharp but friendly, my friend opted for the coffee and a muffin which he liked too.

Overall an ok place and alternative option to coffee lovers and non-coffee drinkers alike.
author: Johnas D.

description:
Stopped in around 11:30 one weekday morning by myself, and loved the design and bustling atmosphere and menu.  I had the BLAP (like a BLT with pear and avocado) and really enjoyed it (I wanted the avocado toast with egg but breakfast had just ended).  

I hate to be that person, but I wish they'd limit the free wifi.  I barely found a place to sit because every spot had someone camped out with their laptop.  There's a long row of tables for two, and each table had just one person ... and their laptop.  Or maybe they could add a communal table for folks with laptops.  I'll definitely be back, but I'm not looking forward to the seating situation.
author: Lynn S.

description:
My hunt for the ultimate coffee shop continues, and so far, Reveille is in the lead :D I've been a Philz phanatic for years, but sometimes I really just need a latte. Wandered down the street to find this place. Not only are the lattes here top notch, but they have the PERFECT breakfast/lunch menu. Had the Egg and Avocado on Toast for breakfast, then stuck around for lunch and had the Kale salad. Kale, eggs, and avo are pretty much my favorite foods, so this place is heaven sent :)) Not to mention the super friendly, non-pretentious staff and great chill music selection.

 I've spent about three hours here now, and moving to the Castro has crossed my head multiple times :P
author: K C.

description: Great atmosphere, yummy quinoa salad, avocado toast and iced almond latte :) free wifi pass longhairdontcare ;)
author: Aga S.

description:
Join me.

For coffee: http://www.yelp.com/biz/r%C3%A9veille-coffee-co-truck-san-francisco?hrid=4IKsT7Ne77UHcEyn1Lbr4g

For homemade granola, peanut butter and cookies: http://www.yelp.com/biz/r%C3%A9veille-coffee-co-san-francisco-5?hrid=LmYwvodmncQBm_49EWvgmA

For flatbread: Unique to the Castro is an impressively large (six pieces) and impressively tasting thin crust topped with homemade marinara sauce, mozzarella and basil. Just $8.

Also topped with olive oil along with more given on the side but overall surprisingly light.

This location also includes a small entrance patio, wood tables, free WiFi, beautiful lighting and conversation starter table signs that say "Hi! Please join me at this table."

Consider yourself invited.
author: Jason B.

description: The coffee and avocado toast were amazing, and the girl at the counter was really nice. Though it was crowded we were able to find a seat on a bench in front. Overall a good experience
author: Olivia K.

description: I was very excited to find this place in the Castro today. Fantastic almond milk latte. Beautiful, clean shop and friendly baristas. Cute little outdoor area. What more do you need?
author: Nicole C.

description: Their coffee has one of the finest flavors I've found. Hard to describe the purity of taste and perfect preparation. The employees make you feel welcomed and appreciated.
author: Henry M.

description: A bit of a crowded place but servers delicious espresso drinks with almond milk. Richeon frothy. Good places to set but acoustics makes it hard to hear. Still a great place to check out.
author: around town e.

description:
I've gone on a tour of cafes recently as I looked for the perfect place to study. This place gets all five stars.

The pros:

+ The ambience is fantastic. The lighting is bright and the interior design is sleek. It feels both modern and safe
+ The wifi is free. Unlike cafes like Sophie's which charge you per hour, Reveille offers you an unlimited stream of wifi. For the most part, it's fast, too
+ The wide selection of food and drinks. To be fair, I haven't had any food besides the Chinese Chicken Salad, which is 3/5, but the number of options seems favorable

The cons:

- Always busy. I've come at all times of the day and have rarely found the cafe not totally packed. If you're looking for a lot of space to call your own, this may not be it

- No outlets. If you're a student or someone who needs a fully powered laptops for hours to complete his work, beware. There is one outlet in the entire cafe, and as you can imagine, it's usually taken. Consider yourself time-limited

I can tell you this place is the best in the neighborhood. Illy Cafe is behind it. Sweet Inspiration behind that. Sophie's has a ridiculous wifi policy (1 hour per purchase), so i wouldn't recommend it if you value wifi
author: Aj P.

description: Coffee is strong and good. Yum Yum.
author: Mel G.

description: Simply one of the best places for coffee and people watching in one of the best neighborhoods in SF. Amazing staff and cool atmosphere.
author: Jed R.

description: Great place to meet a friend, or work all day. Order the PB&J and a glass of milk and you'll be both full and happy. While getting a seat can be hard given its small size, once you score a spot you never want to leave.
author: Jeff M.

description: Loved this place right off Castro. Definite order the PBJ as a snack. I needed a little pick me up late in the afternoon and it was perfect.
author: Alvaro M.

description: Super hipster cafe. The cappuccino is pretty tasty and also very presentable, as you can tell from all the yelp pictures. Kind of overpriced, but you pay for the environment. The tables are big, lighting is good, free wifi, and there's a good amount of space both inside and outside. Also, the people who work here are nice (because they complimented me on my necklace hehe).
author: Christina L.

description:
Everything is amazing, especially the staff!!!

Great place to work or study. 

Employees are happy and upbeat and nice. 

Coffee is good!
author: Nicole B.

description:
Small, low-key, and quality-conscious.  Pleasant staff.  Robust house coffee.

It's OK that it's a limited menu - they did a good job of our two meals.

Avocado, bacon & egg open-faced breakfast toast was fresh and tasty.  Chia pudding topped with fresh fruit was overpriced yet pleasant and mild.
author: Anne J.

description: Delicious food. Delicious cappuccinos. Cute, clean, simple spot. Friendly service, and festive atmosphere! Outdoor seating is great for nice weather.
author: Mely M.

description: Good coffee, food, music AND a friendly demeanor are a winning combo to help a customer start their day right. The cold brew coffee tasted balanced and velvety -- not bitter or acidic like at some coffee shops that leave you wondering if it's actually just regular coffee on ice. The Shakshuka (poached egg/kale/tomato/chickpea/feta) breakfast bowl was delicious and filling. Generally I would cast a side of toast aside but even the Starter Bakery levain that came with the dish looked (and was) too good to pass up. Also they were playing music by FKA Twigs and two people working there complimented me on my outfit.
author: Kyle L.

description: This place has a great vibe, excellent coffees,  teas and food. They have a little front patio ideal to sip your drink. Nirvana was playing when we went there!
author: Valentina B.

description:
I just recently found this place (even though it's a block from my house), and I LOVE IT. The food, the atmosphere, the staff ... everything is amazing. They have a brunch menu that switches out to lunch at some point in the day - they are both pretty small menus, but all of the food I've tried so far has been delicious. 

It's an order at the counter kind of place - very relaxed. My only gripe is that it's always busy, no matter when I come in. Yet I still magically always manage to find a place to sit (they also offer little table share cards so you can let others know when you are open to sharing your table). 

They have a cute little outside patio area which looks out onto 18th street - a nice respite from what can be a pretty grimy part of the Castro. They also have free WiFi, and their Chai's are yummy.
author: Julia O T.

description: The coffee was wonderful and the food choices were all a man could want. It also helped that the staff was adorable
author: Isaiah L.

description:
These people are busy and friendly (most of them) and again, their coffee is great. This place feels nice to hang out in, though I wish customers were a little more social. 

Still growing on me and ignore my past reviews, haha, must have been a bad day.
author: Christopher J.

description:
A great addition to the neighborhood.

Excellent coffee, especially the pour-over. What makes this place special is the food menu. Breakfast sandwich? Yes, please!

The interior is clean, modern and cozy; plenty of tables and chairs to go around.
author: Charlie A.

description:
What a great little coffee shop! 
- The interiors are all wood panels and white benches, giving it a really clean look. 
- We ordered a mocha, coffee and the seasonal flatbread, which had grilled asparagus - yum! The mocha was good, a little strong though. 
- The staff were really friendly and smiley :)
- Only downside was that it got a little cramped for space. Otherwise, it's a nice place to sit and enjoy your drink. Definitely recommended!
author: Pooja S.

description:
City by the Bay has many coffee shops to offer San Franciscans from small locally owned stores to large corporates. However, due to current movement of producing high-quality coffee, so many coffee shops opened up that serve amazing coffee. One of them is of course Réveille Coffee Co. This truly unparalleled coffee was first served just few years ago by two brothers through a delivery truck. Once you try third-wave (high quality) coffee, you just can't go back, especially if you tried Réveille coffee. 

This particular Réveille Coffee location in Castro offers a small store with plenty of seating for a small space. Also, there is a tiny outside area where it is so nice to have a cup of coffee on a sunny day. The baristas are fun at this location and always are welcoming. 

In addition to serving amazing coffee, Réveille offers a wide selection of sandwiches. Despite the fact that there are plenty of food items to choose from, I always ordered the same chicken sandwich whenever I ate at Réveille.
author: Aigul K.

description: Great mix of music, great coffee, great black and white wall paper, great place. I even got a big lemon cake for free, since they closed a little earlier.
author: Kristina H.

description:
What a lovely new coffee shop! The atmosphere is beautiful, clean, modern and cozy inside.  The black and white tiles behind the counter are great.  There is wi-fi, but no electrical outlets. 

I had the vanilla latte- wow, definitely the best latte I have ever had.  The vanilla flavor is made in house.  The service was friendly and quick (no snobbiness or annoyance at questions- which drives me crazy in SF). The barista was really smiley and seemed to really enjoy making latte art and watching us compare art with the patrons at the table next to us.

The food looked good, but we didn't try anything.

I will definitely return.
author: Christy L.

description: One of my favorite cafes in sf. Very friendly stuff, delicious food. Salads and sandwiches are way better than what u would expect from a cafe. Nice atmosphere but charging your laptop or phone is a problem here.
author: Çağlar A.

description: Great coffee and snacks (PB&J Toast is awesome). Lovely atmosphere with a few seats outside in the front. The staff are friendly and on top of everything. Highly recommended.
author: James B.

description:
Hip spot with morning sunshine and some outdoor seating, serving breakfast til 1 pm. I love breakfast sandwiches  - which makes for a great crossover menu item if you are looking for lunch early, as I was today. Breakfast sandwich with egg and avocado on freshly made toast was delicious and served quickly.

Awesomely courteous and attentive staff. It's President's Day, and he toasted to a woman prez, coming soon to a country near us! Me and my friend appreciated the woman shout out.

Family-friendly too.
author: Roxanne D.

description: Nice staff, cool music, clean cafe and they open early on Saturdays! The coffee is very tasty. I will stop by again next time I'm in the neighborhood.
author: Marc R.

description:
One of my favorite cafés in the city. 

Free wifi, genial baristas, and an incredible atmosphere. Lighting, music, decor, and taste of the coffee - everything pretty much just works!
author: Tony D.

description: Pretty place & perfect location. Service was 4/5. However, the main part- the coffee was a 1/5. I got a mocha & thought it was overpriced and horrible. Even my friend who got HOT CHOCOLATE hated it. How hard is it to make hot coco? Everything but the coffee itself was great. Most likely not going to come back.
author: Pavnit K.

description:
Nicest baristas in the city, and great food, too! Love hanging out in the sunny sidewalk seating on the weekend. Protip: sun hits that side of the street around 11am. 

Bring your sunglasses and workout shirts, it gets really hot!
author: Jessie Y.

description: Stopped into Réveille for coffee and a snack on a Saturday afternoon. As expected, it was busy, but I found a spot at the bar in the center of the café. Even with six people's tickets ahead of mine, my latte was ready in just a couple of minutes. Carefully poured and plated. The avocado toast came out quickly afterwards, and was well seasoned, although the bread (a French country?) was surprisingly dry. Excellent customer service: while working quickly, the three counter people were all really nice and conversational. Cool location, too, as it's conveniently tucked into the ground floor of the building and away from the street, with clean, contemporary decor. I'll be back!
author: Brian C.

description: A really cool coffee shop. I got avocado toast and a cold brew. The avocado toast is great- they don't skimp on the avocado. The cold brew was also really good- sometimes a cold brew can be too bitter but this one didn't have that problem. It has a good environment there- good place to come with a book or laptop (though I'm not too sure about wifi or outlets).
author: Kim V.

description:
I was so stoked the first time I came by. I've worked in the hood for 3+ years and it's been nearly impossible to grab a fresh, delicious lunch anywhere on the street. The food in the Castro available during lunch is dismal at best. So when I tried the oh-so-amazing goat cheese salad I almost did a backflip from excitement. I could eat here every day of the week and don't even mind the $15 price tag for a salad + chai tea. 

But, honestly, what's up with the customer service? You walk in to a bunch of kids milling about behind the counter, receive no greeting, no welcoming, no "what can I get you?!". Instead it's just blank stares all around. So extremely awkward! Each time I go back it gets worse. My coworkers who I've recommended the place to got the same reaction. One friend even walked right out. 

I'll stay neutral at 3 stars but pull it together please! This neighborhood needs you!!!
author: Shawna Q.

description:
I like this place a lot.   Only major complaint is that  I am a tea drinker and it would be nice if they have a more generic  black english breakfast tea but can't be too picky.

 Just had the chicken sandwich and it was as good as a chicken sandwich could be.  They used real rotisserre meat, good quality bread (think it was acme), not too much cheese, and arugla side salad was dressed perfectly with right amount of acid.  I hate how places  put too little acid in dishes.

Also people said the service is lacking in their reviews.  I could not disagree more.  The service is amazing here on all four different visits and I am NOT a pretty castro boy or girl just you average joe person.    The only thing I would dock them for is value.  The value is not bad but not amazing either..... its acceptable,  but on the other hand the quality of food is better than starbucks and you get more so I guess you get what you pay for.

One more thing the crowd is not as disheveled  and roudy as the starbucks  on 18th street.

Food 4 Stars
Service 5 Stars
Atmosphere 5 Stars
Value 3.5 Stars
author: Christopher T.

description: Delicious yogurt with homemade granola and cold brew coffee. $10 is not a steal, but it seemed worth it at the time (especially when my other option is Starbucks). Pretty crowded on a Monday at noon, so I can't imagine what weekends are like (but understand why they would turn off wifi on the weekends).
author: Janelle F.

description: Exceptional service. Really tasty food and coffee. HUGE fan. I come here all the time.
author: L A.

description: So far the best coffee I've been directed to in the area. Service is usually pretty good if a little San Franciscan (low key and somewhat indifferent). Sandwiches are also good if you're in need of food. When it gets busy, as it often is, there is little available seating and the temperature makes you wonder if you're next to a boiler room. This being SF there is usually a bevy of people working (or not) on laptops and sundry devices without regard to their environment.
author: G A.

description:
I think  that the only good thing about this place is the Wifi, coffee itself isn't good actually has a weird sour taste (i know taste is subjective, but......)
The eggs sandwiches didn't came out as the menu says, the attitude in general was no nice, but probably this is the new way to interact with costumers.
author: Frank C.

description:
Great espresso drinks, award-winning breakfast sandwich, nice space, though Very Loud. I'm happy they are here, as they make for a nice breakfast experience and chat and they have a fair amount of space, though your ears will be ringing when you leave if they are at all busy.

Service is mixed, sometimes they can be very friendly, and sometimes really brusque and a bit hipster. However, they are better than so many four star locations that I can't help but give them the 5th one.
author: Scott L.

description:
This new cafe is too nice to denigrate with a "hipster" label, as some of the earlier Yelp reviewers have done. (Don't you all know hipster = bad?)

Good coffee, beautiful interior design and -- tah-dah! -- it has that rarest of Castro amenities: outdoor seating.
author: Jim H.

description: Great coffee, friendly staff and sun-drenched (tiny) terrace in the heart of Castro make a great trio
author: Olivia M.

description: Latte was really good.  Grilled chicken sandwich is another recommendation.  Very trendy. Had outside seating too.
author: Hiral P.

description: Wow... That was the best dirty chai I have ever had in my life! The spices so nice and the buzz was so elegant :) The business itself is very clean and carries a classy and elegant ambience. Will be returning!
author: Erik C.

description: More sour coffee for the $8 toast crowd! If you're drinking here...you're like 20 feet from Philz. Go to Philz.
author: Luke M.

description:
Love this new place in the Castro. Beats Starbucks any time of the day. Wonderful ambiance and super tasty coffee. 
Staff is beautiful.
author: N H.

description: Great coffee, but waiting 35 minutes for a basic chicken sandwich at 2pm- when it isn't crowded is unacceptable. I asked them to check what was talking so long, and they came back and didn't say anything for another 10 minutes. The ONLY reason I am writing this review is because this is the second and LAST time that this is happened here.
author: David F.

description: Simply wonderful! The staff is friendly and knowledgeable. The space is open, inviting and spotlessly clean. The coffee was smooth, rich, and heaven to drink. I have found my new favorite coffee shop!
author: Picture M.

description: Great space, good coffee and although way too sweetened almond milk...much else pretty good. Thanks for coming to the Castro.
author: Kate S.

description: I've been religiously going to Réveille Coffee Co for months now in Castro. I love it because they have free wifi that's fast, delicious coffee (and I hate coffee), food that is worth every nickel and a down to earth staff that makes you feel at home. One of the cooks named John created this watermelon salad that isn't even on the menu (yet) but is a must try. Bottom line, I've been living in San Francisco for 8 years and this is the only cafe hands down that you'll want to come back too very often.
author: Ray C.

description: All the gays come here. Okay some of the gays come here. You'll get a couple of dykes, and hipsters. The coffee is great, and the tea is a bit expensive. Just go to Starbucks for the tea. Just saying.
author: Vinson H.

description: After seeing this today I'm no longer buying coffee here. No other business in the area is blocking parking on fri night except them. Really disappointing when a business take a political stance at the expense of the neighborhood. Many people/customers drive into San Francisco just to support and spend money on local businesses. I don't even own a vehicle but it's Poor judgement and taste to setting up tables and chairs to block parking to advertise and make a profit. for your companies gain. These people were pretty nice it's surprising they are having their employees sit out there to give the appearance of customers blocking the street. There's many options within a 1 block  radius to purchase $4 coffees. No one ever blocked parking for the 18 months it took for the construction to gut out the garage to make this company. Was a lot of dirt, dust and noise for us in the neighborhood and this is how they are choosing to show their gratitude to the locals and surrounding neighbors.
author: Mike R.

description:
And now on one block there's Philz, Ritual (at UB), and now Four Barrel here at Reveille. Goodness. I can't say it enough but the low hanging coffee fruit in SF is some of the best damn fruit around. I'm not sure how busy the other location in North Beach gets... the couple of times I was there it was sparse, likely because tourists don't always know a good local business when they see one at first glance. Here in this neighborhood though... there's already a line and a buzz about this location. The kitchen is serving some serious breakfast sandwiches, and a sunny (read: often in the Castro) day, there's some patio space, and a line out front. I'm sure that the coffee chains will always have a small foothold in the competition but it's becoming easier and easier for anyone to get a good, quick cup of coffee without having to order their preferred method of brewing and without having to order something that's not the seven letter word of joy. Simply: Hi. Coffee. Please. 

Note: communal two-sided wood bar for quick, easy seating.
author: Jon A.

description:
I wanted to like this place so bad, I really did. Went in around lunchtime on 3/19 with my cousin visiting from NYC ( i was excited to show her the new coffee spot in the neighborhood) and was greeted by no one. The guy behind the register just stared at us when we approached, no even making eye contact and making us feel super uncomfortable.

After we got our drinks from the barista, I asked for some cold almond milk (big mistake) to add to my triple espresso. After adding the milk, the espresso curdled instantly and was undrinkable. I approached the vacant guy at the register again and he simply pointed to the barista. I explained what had happened to my drink and the barista went and got the "manager" He told me that their coffee tends to curdle when it comes in contact with almond milk and then proceeded to pour out the almond milk into a glass and taste test it in front of me and saying that it tasted fine to him. It was like he was trying to place blame on me or something. I don't need a lesson, I just want to get my coffee and head to Dolores Park with my visiting cousin. 20 minutes after I first placed my original coffee order, I finally got my replacement triple shot served with an overwhelming side of embarrassment and feeling like I should have just gone to Starbucks.
author: Will K.

description: It is a really nice space, but I don't know why they'd overlook readily available power outlets when designing the space. That'd probably keep me from coming back.
author: Eloy R.

description: So originally I started going to Reveille when they opened.  It was completely 5 stars.  I will say that the staff there has always been and still is 5 star.  Unfortunately the quality of the food has steadily diminished.  The biscuits, a signature item here, use to be light airy and deliciously buttery.  I don't know if they completely abandoned their old recipe for a new one...but disappointing. Before I didn't mind paying a bit of a premium for the food here....now not so much. Happy to pay for great food, unfortunately this is no longer great food.  Ugh....the search for an amazing coffee shop begins again.
author: Jason F.

description: First time here and may I say it was fantastic! Good people and good vibes not to mention a pretty awesome menu! Most definitely 100% customer satisfaction for me!
author: Shaniah M.

description: Good coffee, wifi, nice ambiance, and friendly staff. I like the "share my table" signs. Good place to go get some work done!
author: Michelle K.

description: A bizarrely 2nd-order coffee place. Beautiful interior with excellent furnishings but one gets the unmistable sense that the place is lined with money in a vaguely treacly way. Like a slightly nauseating ability to perfect an aesthetic derived from a glut of misallocated general social funds. The coffee's good but only insofar as you enjoy light-medium roasts as this is a place that makes a fetish of the lighter roast. To be honest, go get yourself a less expensive cup. Good but not going back.
author: Houston D.

description:
I use to go to Reveille every weekend while I was doing laundry.  The atmosphere is great, and the employees are the best.  Their coffee prices are about $1.00 more than Starbucks or Peets, but I went anyway as I enjoyed the vibe.  Recently they decided to turn off wifi on weekends.  A coffee shop without wifi on weekends?

I no longer go to Reveille, although I miss it.  I hope they decide to change their policy on wifi, it shouldn't be all about getting customers in and out as quickly as possible.
author: John ..

description: Perfect addition to the neighborhood.  Outstanding and attentive service. Smart crew. Excellent breakfast sandwich (I've been thinking about ever since). Decor is slick and sparse. A definite cut above for this neighborhood. And a great soundtrack.
author: Monster B.

description: The coffee is artisanal and delicious while the decor recalls the mess hall of a 19th century Danish whaling ship. Get the breakfast sandwich with braised kale and leek, Gruyere and bacon. The staff are courteous and cordial.
author: Andrew K.

description: Love the ambiance,  strong coffee & strong wifi. Avocado toast is delicious, the egg sandwich beautifully constructed. Only missing one star for the dearth of outlets!
author: Emily R.

description: Friendly prompt service. The soy latte was OK. The food looked delicious; I'll have to come back to try it. Cute coffee shop to get some work done!
author: Sneha P.

description: I really liked their new location in Castro and found it better than the one in north beach. Interior decor is so bright and modern, they have bunch of good options plus outside seating are under Castro sun. I'm sold!
author: Beril Y.

description: Great coffee, nice outdoor area and funky indoor area. Great service and the food that was coming out looked great too.
author: Livia M.

description: I was pleasantly surprised by Reveille in the Castro. It's tucked away in a really interesting renovated garage space on 18th Street and it carries a cozy neighborhood vibe, serving as a calmer alternative to bustling Castro Street. The line moved fast and, even on a Saturday afternoon, there was plenty of seating. There's also a cute outdoor seating area out front if you want to people-watch. I had a delicious iced latte and the cold brew.
author: Priscilla L.

description: This place is quite pricey for coffee, but, hands down, they've got the best almond milk cappuccino I've had in the city. Their egg/bacon/kale sandwich is delicious too. Cute and comfortable locale.
author: Shahrzad K.

description: I'm sure the coffee is good, but my lunch was inedible and the service matched the food.
author: Sanford S.

description: Great space, questionable service. Stopped by for coffee. All milk containers were empty and when I mentioned it to the guy behind the counter he didn't really to care or ask if I needed any. The coffee is ok but Philz doesn't have anything to worry about. I think it may be an ok place to spend some time chatting with a friend, but it's nothing special.
author: Joe S.

description: The avocado toast is amazing! The only problem is one is not enough! The avocado toast is so good I want to eat like 10 of them which is sort of a problem, because its almost $5 each....
author: Moran G.

description: Fav place for great coffee, imaginative and tasty food, wifi/working space, and third-place meetings in the Castro. Plus the staff is consistently engaging and efficient.
author: Tim J.

description: Nice hipster coffee shop with a bit of everything and a lot of personality. With a bit of luck this will place will steal plenty of business from Starbucks. After Starbucks up the street remodeled becoming a cold and boring corporate location this place is a breath of fresh air.
author: Bartholomew F.

description: The coffee is still good, but there are too many people here working on their computers for this to be my favorite cafe any more. Too bad, the coffee and the food are pretty good.
author: Meredith G.

description: Great coffee!! Egg sandwich is amazing! But expect to wait a long time if you ordered breakfast. Two times in a row I had to go back to the kitchen to check on my order after waiting for more than 15 mins.
author: Shelly H.

description: Went here for the first time today with a friend. The prices are shockingly inexpensive for being a hipster place in the middle of the Castro in the US's most expensive city. I didn't have coffee, but the avocado and egg on toast was delicious. The only downside is that the cashier was a little "yeah, whatever" and didn't seem too interested in the customers, but as it was a Tuesday morning, I don't blame him.
author: Lia R.

description: This is sort of like the heaven of all coffeeshops. It feels peaceful here, even when it's bustling. I like to sit here and read "Pride and Prejudice," or take a Spanish lesson on Duolingo, drinking a hot tea and eating something delicious. I'm a fan of the roasted chicken sandwich and particularly the BLAP, which, though it sounds like something unfortunate that happens during sex, is actually a sandwich that involves bacon and avocado, two of my favorite things.
author: Kent L.
