description: Reveille came to the Castro and immediately drew a crowd. I stopped in on the first day and was impressed with the service and clean lines of the decor, had a hushed and leisurely chat with a friend in the corner, and left happy. I came back a week later and it was standing room only. Good for them! Prices are the same as every other coffee shop in the city (meaning you are lucky to escape for less than $4.5 for a hot beverage), but they do have a frequent buyer card where you get one free beverage for every 13 purchased, so be sure to ask for it if you plan to be a regular.
author: Marie F.

description: Best coffee shop in San Francisco. I've always met interesting people here willing to strike up a conversation. Their PB&J toast transported me to another plane of existence. Employees are crazy friendly and the coffee is super good. Also, lots of good lookin' gays. Just sayin.
author: Caleb Z.

description: I really didn't want to like this place. It's super pricey. $2.50 for BYO mug drip coffee. Hm. That's a lot. They baked goods - wow! And the coffee is REALLY DELICIOUS! It's just so expensive and trendy and crowded and I have the same haircut as all of the boys working
author: Megan S.

description: I'm a totally fan of lattes that go down smooth, are strong, and do not require me to add sugar! And Reveille Coffee Co. has that! They have a cool space with good vibes, just be sure if you're coming here to work, your devices are fully charged, there is literally one plug/outlet to charge up.
author: Josie C.

description: This place is super laid back with plenty of locals. Lots of beautiful people. We almost could not focus on our food die to the hotness  try the avocado fried egg breakfast. One thing I do not get is the add on tip when you are paying at the register. But it is a nice spot so enjoy.
author: Yaya L.

description: Enjoyed the hearty egg sandwich here. Also love the service and ambience of the place.
author: Xteethx B.

description: Newly opened (as I'm told) I sought haven from the downpour at this Castro cafe. Slick modern monochromatic tiles greet you before you're met by a chipper young chap behind the counter who takes your order. Using this as an opportunity to grab brunch, I order a cappucino and a grilled chicken sandwich (it had me at apple slaw!). The small 2-person tables against the back wall were, as I imagine they often are, occupied by the laptop army so I perched myself upon a stool at the communal bench. I was overcome to see my sandwich came with a side of salad and not chips! The coffee was perfectly poured and stands out as one of the better American coffees I've had.
author: Lani P.

description: The availability of healthy choices in the Castro is limited.  We have plenty of burritos, pizza, and sliders - and now finally we have fresh sandwiches and salads.  Reveille bills itself as a coffee house (and the coffee is amazing) but the magic is in the quinoa salad (pro-tip, add chicken) or the toasted B.L.A.P. (the P is for roasted pear).  The staff is friendly and unpretentious, and even when the line is crazy and the seats are all taken, it's the best bet in several square blocks.
author: Jeffrey M.

description: So chic, cute baristas, good chef, open, white-washed, Franco, and modern; it's your bourgeois-hipster alternative to Starbucks.
author: Patrick M.

description: The space, the staff, and the food at Réveille are top-notch. It's a great addition to the neighborhood. The espresso (both regular and decaf) are consistently excellent.
author: Christopher B.

description: $2.50 for a cup of in house coffee and $1.50 for refill?? Are you serious and the coffee was not comparable to the North Beach standards. Next time I will just go up a few blocks and  get the real stuff and leave this place to the hipsters and tourist......
author: R H.

description: Yes, I'm a fan.  Great addition to the 'stro and a fantastic alternative to Starbucks just down the block.  Coffee is great, but the food is awesome - I shared one of the flat bread items and it was delish.  Also great breakfast sandwiches.  I'll be back.
author: Jim D.

description: Great coffee. Great vibe. Great staff. Great atmosphere. So happy to have them in my hood
author: Matt V.

description: 2nd time here, still a great place for coffee, though a bit tough to find a seat to do work in the middle of the afternoon. Thanks again to that cute barista who claimed I'm "rocking my hoodie". Nothing beats good espresso and free compliments!
author: Rodney A.

description: The place is nice but the people are not. I asked for the wifi password and was given it. After I couldn't find the network, I asked for the name and a female barista nastily said it was turned off. No explanation. Don't come here for the wifi !!
author: Emily F.

description: Good coffee for commuters. Not a great place if you have to log in to do some work briefly as it has no internet connection -- I our case. Barista said that hr Internet was not reliable and didn't comp the drinks as we clearly went there to catch up and jump on wifi briefly.
author: Angel C.

description: Having been in the US for 12 days (this time) it was very refreshing to come across two coffee bars in the same day that serve real coffee. No offence to any US citizens but ordinarily, coffee is no more than a brown novelty drink.  Reveille however, knows and understands how to serve coffee. We ordered two espresso which were served with a courteous smile, and followed by a very knowledgeable conversation about the origin and mix of the beans that went into our drinks. After chatting with us our server offered us a free espresso and joined us to hear our comments and offer her opinions on it depth of flavours. If you know anything about coffee you will know that this is a place to go and that the neighbour two doors away, is to be avoided at all cost. I only wish this place  (just 2 months old) a long and prosperous life, and that it has thrived and grown before our next visit.
author: Stephen C.

description:
I am disappointed to report that Réveille Coffee has come back on their promise to serve their granola/yogurt dish in the afternoon. On 3/4/2014 their chef promised to me they would not limit it to breakfast time, and I filed an excellent review based on that.
I am removing one star for Réveille not serving a dish that most cafés in San Francisco offer in the afternoon, and another star for lying to me. Granola with yogurt is a very healthy and enjoyable afternoon treat. Cafés should set their rules based on customer satisfaction. Boo to the Réveille management for choosing to set up rigid rules.
author: Guillermo G.

description: In the 6 weeks since my first review, Reveille has really stepped up in the service department.  I see the same, friendly, competent faces, and the line moves now.  The food continues to be fantastic.  As is the coffee.  This is a high end cafe.  So expect to pay more.  This is now my go to lunch/coffee place.  Just wish the table hogs sucking up bandwidth would limit their stay to under an hour. How does 1 coffee, equal taking up table space for 2 hours???
author: EC N.

description: Great coffee and the best kale salad!!!  I have one every week .. And often must add a flatbread for good measure.  A highlight of our weekend.  So happy this coffee house/eatery has moved to our neighborhood!
author: Lauren G.

description:
These guys are great. Good coffee, very tasty food. As a recent Aussie transplant I've been looking for my weekend breakfast spot and Reveille tops the list for me right now. 

Favourite items on the menu are the egg and bacon sandwich, the kale salad with turkey and the flatbreads. 

One thing: I wish they had juices. Everything else I am digging. Keep it up!
author: Verne S.

description: Overall I really, really like Reveille. The place itself is really cool and comfortable, everyone who works here is very nice, and everything is delicious. I've liked all the food I've ordered here and think they do a great job with their coffee. Unfortunately they recently raised their coffee prices and I personally think it's now far too expensive. $3 for a small, already-brewed-sitting-in-a-giant-carafe is way too much. I used to go here a few times a week but now I go once a week or less.
author: Anna S.

description: A beautiful coffee shop in the perfect little spot. It's a great alternative to Starbucks in the Castro. The quality of the hot chocolate and the teas are really excellent.
author: Matt G.

description: I've only been once, so I don't have a lot to go on. Pros: good coffee, nice decor, outdoor seating. Cons: coffee is expensive, too many stools instead of real chairs, loud music. Struck me as better for lunch with a friend, than as someplace you would want to sit with your computer.
author: Just R.

description: Nice coffee, nice location, nice decor, slow-slow-slow service. Consistently this coffee place takes their sweet time to make any of the drinks and they are consistently very nonchalant about it. Philz can take the order, grind the beans, mix it how you want it and take half the time of Reveille.
author: Dr F.

description:
DONT COME HERE! ...I want it all to myself :)

Such a rad spot with super nice staff. The menu is a little hidden next to the register, so if there's a long line you best look it up because there's lots of amazing food to pick from!
author: Will T.

description: Hipster cool and simplistically clean decor (white and wood) is a nice compliment to the robust and smooth coffee!
author: Stef G.

description: It's about time a nice fashionable low key place opened in the Castro. This is exactly what the neighborhood needed. Great decor. Friendly. Good food and coffee.  Definitely go. You'll love it.  And if you don't, well you should.
author: Chris M.

description: Fresh and modern, those are the two words that define this amazing cafe! There food is amazing, its officially my new dinner spot!
author: Adedai K.

description: Used to be amazing, sorta gone downhill in recent months. On the most recent visit, the cafe interior smelled extremely bad, the coffee was bitter (not in the good way), and the music was boring.
author: Viren J.

description:
Just stopped by for my first time this morning for some coffee and breakfast. 

Very friendly staff (although for some reason there were ONLY men employees, no women, which was a little weird to me) but despite that they were all very friendly, very beautiful interior design (great ambience, very clean)-they even had a cute ass bathroom.

The coffee was great, I ordered a latte. I usually like my coffee sweet but I didn't need to add any sugar, the natural flavor of great coffee and milk was just right. For my breakfast I orderd the egg sandwhich, it was delicious! The bread was amazing, the egg, kale, (and I think cheese was in there) were all very flavorful-it kind of tasted like a quiche. My meal cost me $12.

This place has great coffee and food and a beautiful interior/ambience. This place made me feel classy. If you're ever in the Castro I think you'll have a good experience here.
author: Jena W.

description:
Nothing wrong with a good ol' hipster cafe. When I asked how it was pronounced, the guy behind the counter said it was "ri-Vay": "Ri" as in ribbon and "vay" like "Oy vey!" Anyway, I'm not a coffee drinker, I come here for the tea. I could see it being kind of annoying, but I actually appreciate the fact that they seep your tea for you (assuming they aren't re-seeping the same leaves after someone else's order.)
Edit: After going back to try Reveille as an internet cafe, I was annoyed by 3 things: One: Though they clearly encourage people to work on their computers, there are NO outlets. Once your computer runs out (very quickly for mine) then you'll have to move on. Two: The shakshuka, which was recommended to my by a friend, is not available after breakfast. Instead I had the avocado toast, which is pretty good. For some reason they treat it as a breakfast item. Third: I'm from the south, and I don't particularly like my iced tea to taste that floral.
author: Nik K.

description: $3.00 for a small cup of iced tea.  I didn't know that gold can be made into iced tea????  wow
author: Bennie F.

description: finally! a nice relaxing coffee shop in the Castro with lots of decent seating (including a nice front patio), music that isn't meant for a dance club, good pastries, friendly staff, and open past 7pm. hallelujah.
author: LA M.

description: Tasty breakfast options (if a smidge limited). No decaf iced coffee, but they can do iced espresso drinks so that works. BEAUTIFUL space to sit and enjoy your coffee/food, either with your existing friends or with new ones at the communal tables.
author: Roger G.

description: great coffee and great staff. I went in for a late night coffee and after I put in sugar and milk it was warm. I love hot coffee! Maybe it was their last pot. I asked if they had any way to warm it up. I was offered another cup and after trying it black it just was not hot enough. The barista asked if I would like an Americano. I took a double Americano and yes it was piping hot!! They were awesome and I felt they were really concerned and were happy to help. Thanks Revielle coffee! They also serve breakfast and lunch. I'll be back!
author: V M.

description: Hipster ditch cafe filled with CAMPERS that hog the tables for hours with their laptops. Too bad, because even though the coffee is bad, the food is great!
author: Christopher S.

description: Their iced lattes are anything but watered down. It had the perfect balance and I actually liked it better than the way they make it at four barrel even though they use the same beans. Tried half of the egg breakfast sandwich and half of the avocado toast with egg and they were both very flavorful with perfectly cooked Sunnyside up eggs. This place will definitely be receiving a visit from me in the near future!
author: J M.

description: I was in the City and thought I would try something different. REVEILLE COFFEE looked nice. Long line, must be good. Turned out to be a long line because it was a slow line. I agree with others about the attitude...and so early in the morning. Asked for the wireless password, which turned out to be a phrase with the word "don't" in it. I spell don't with an apostrophe. Not them. I asked a second time and got a good dose of the acclaimed attitude. I guess they don't put an apostrophe in don't. Had a looked-good-but-just-OK egg sandwich for $7.50, with a cup of black coffee, $11.15 total. Ouch. But OK, it's San Francisco. However, the oddest thing they do is, after they enter your order into their computer screen, they turn the screen towards you and have you then choose a tip amount from three choices on screen. It looked as if it was -$1-$2 -or $3 if you got just a drink, and 15%- 20% -or 25% if you got more than just a drink.  I can't say this for sure, but it's my best guess. And of course everyone in line is watching you, so you don't dare be cheap. This place may be trendy, but not for me.
author: J S.

description: mmmmmmm I like love this place
author: Frustrated W.

description: Ohh so nice and so clean...live the vibe the coffee and all the helpful & eager staff. I know it's new in the neighborhood I just hope it doesn't loses it's charm. Staff is great and the vibe is nice.
author: Elena T.

description: Beautiful space, very tasteful ! Now, the staff needs to be more hospitable, friendly and not so "cool and hip". Smile ! Take away that "attitude" or nonchalant behavior, as if you were so "unique". It's just coffee ! I'll give it another try and hope they get it. Or hire better employees with a more friendly personality.
author: Jorge A.

description: very well designed space, indoor and outdoor seating with a cool atmosphere and delicious food.
author: Allison R.

description: IKEA meets attitude meets yoga studio. This place was weird, to say the least. Came in with 2 other friends. One ordered tea, and the rest of us lattes. The women at the counter was vert "peaceful" and pleasant and presented out Tea friend with a very nice tea set, if you will, which was very cool. Sh said we should wait for our lattes which should be ready shortly which she be readyin a bit and to have a seat. No worries, of course, so we had a seat. And we waited. and waited. and waited. and waited. there were maybe 10 p[eople there. No one waiting. Suddenly we barely here the barista (I use the term lighetly) say it was ready. We go and grab them and they were barely warm. he said he had been calling is for some time (?!) with an attitude (I think he is Brazilian  (I am South American myself, so I think I am pretty close). The furniture in that place if it is not IKEA it is VERY close. We start talking and the staff ( NOT the patrons) look at us like we are talking through megaphones) after 15 minutes we get up and leave and head to my Tea friends house. Unless you want to be completely alone and just plug away with your head set and deal with attitutd with cheap furniture, stay away. price wise, same as starbucks.
author: M F.
